PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our opposition to specific changes proposed to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and associated subordinate legislation in the 1993-94 Federal Budget introduced by the Treasurer in the House of Representatives on Tuesday 17 August 1993.

PETITION.TITLE: Rejection of Increase in Leaded Petrol Tax

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The 1993 Federal Budget announced by the Keating Labor Government to increase the excise on leaded fuel by 10 cents per litre.

PETITION.PARA: is a selective, discriminatory tax on owners of older cars;
discriminates against poorer people and country people who own most of these older cars;
will make it more difficult for people to save to purchase newer, more fuel efficient, less-polluting vehicles;

discriminates against South Australia, which produces 70% of Australia's wine;
threatens the continuing existence of 150 smaller wineries and 500 related jobs;
destroys the capacity for a further $500 million, job-creating investment in the wine industry;
will result in lower grape prices for grapegrowers already burdened by the rural recession;
will severely damage the domestic market base for Australian wine which is so essential to its continuing export growth;

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled

(b)It has continually demonstrated itself to be a most efficient shore-based designated Naval facility and Headquarters for the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania;

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to re-enact important provisions of the Copyright Amendment Act 1989 (the Amending Act) in the Copyright Act 1968 (the Principal Act).

The Government has recently been advised by the Chief General Counsel of Australia, Mr Dennis Rose QC, that due to the operation of section 55 of the Constitution the whole of the Amending Act has been invalidated as a result of a decision made by the High Court in March 1993. This opinion was provided after detailed consideration of the terms of the judgment and earlier cases on similar points.

That decision, Australian Tape Manufacturers Association Ltd v The Commonwealth (1993) 112 ALR 53, was concerned with a challenge to the validity of the imposition, in the Amending Act, of a royalty on blank audio tapes. The Court held by a majority of 4 to 3 on this point that the royalty levied on vendors of blank tapes was a tax. In consequence it was invalid by reason of non-compliance with s. 55 of the Constitution.
The first paragraph of s. 55 of the Constitution provides:
"Laws imposing taxation shall only deal with the imposition of taxation and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect.

In his advice Mr Rose notes that "The High Court majority went on to hold that since the "royalty" provisions are inseverably connected with some of the provisions that are invalid because of the first paragraph of s. 55 the "royalty" provisions are also invalid. The result is that all the provisions in the Amending Act are invalid.

In addition to the purported imposition of the blank tape royalty and associated provisions related to home audio taping, the Amending Act gave effect to a number of other very significant changes to Australia's laws on copyright and related rights. These were:

adding new Parts VA and VB to the Principal Act providing for statutory licence schemes for educational and other institutions to copy, respectively, television and radio broadcasts and print copyright works;
adding new Part XIA, providing, for the first time, a range of performers' rights;
clarification of the relationship between the Principal Act and the Designs Act 1906 regarding industrially applied artistic works; and
streamlining the statutory licence for recording musical works.

These amendments were the third stage of important copyright reforms begun in 1984. They were formulated after extensive consultations by the Government with consumers, educators and industry participants. Members from all parties generally supported the 1989 bill and its reforms as being significant additions to the Principal Act. While some aspects of the protection proposed for performers and various matters of detail in drafting were the subject of debate and subsequent amendment during the passage of the legislation, the amendments have been relatively uncontroversial in practice, apart from the blank tape royalty scheme.

I do not intend to repeat a detailed examination of the changes wrought by the Amending Act. Apart from the blank audio tape royalty that the Government has promised to reintroduce separately and associated provisions related to home taping of audio media, an overview of the other provisions of the Amending Act that this Act will retrospectively validate is substantively set out in the Second Reading Speech by the then Attorney-General Bowen beginning at page 2392 in the Hansard report of the 3 November 1988 House of Representative proceedings and beginning at page 3008 in the Hansard report of proceedings of the Senate on 28 November 1988.

I wish to emphasise that the provisions of this bill do not effect any policy change or new initiative. They are directed solely to re-enacting all the amendments to the Principal Act made by the Amending Act except those imposing, and related to the imposition of, the blank tape royalty. The validation is retrospective, operating from the respective dates on which the various provisions of the Amending Act were proclaimed.

There is some variation in the form of the re-enacting provisions. This arises for technical reasons due to the fact that the stages of commencement of various Parts of the Amending Act and the actual dates of deemed commencement of particular sections are now known.

It would be, in the Government's view, inappropriate to reopen any of the issues exhaustively debated late in 1988 and in the early months of 1989. A vast range of commercial and legal arrangements have been set in place, decisions made about the taking or assertion of legal rights and so on, all based on the presumption of the validity of the Amending Act, except, of course, the blank tape royalty. We do not envisage that any person would be unfairly affected by the reinstatement of the law by this bill.

As I have said, the bill is purely technical in nature. The invalidity of these provisions is an unexpected and unfortunate result of a High Court challenge to just one part of a raft of significant measures. I would hope that the Parliament would see the value of their reinstatement and of doing so quickly now that the issue of the invalidity of the provisions has been raised.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering messages Nos 105, 106 and 107 from the House of Representatives relating to the Sales Tax (Customs) (Deficit Reduction) Bill, the Sales Tax (Excise) (Deficit Reduction) Bill, the Sales Tax (General) (Deficit Reduction) Bill and the motion moved by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services that the committee does not press requests Nos 1, 2 and 5 made by the Senate in respect of each of the bills and disagreed to by the House of Representatives. The question is that that motion be agreed to.

—I understand that my colleague Senator Watson intends to make a contribution to this debate soon. I take this opportunity to make a few comments about the messages because the coalition is concerned that we do the right thing on sales tax.

PARA.TAB: We have a lot of difficulties with the government's sales tax regime for the simple reason that the changes in sales tax, which the government introduces in the bills before us today, were not signalled to the Australian population during the election campaign. Much play was made by the government during the election campaign as to how it would save Australia from the goods and services tax. It was not, of course, talking about how it would save Australia from enormous reductions in sales tax—the abolition of sales tax—or how it would save Australian businesses from the removal of billions of dollars in costs, which is what the Fightback package would have achieved. We did not hear that. We did not hear the government saying, `By the way, we will add sales tax costs to business', which is the consequence of this. We will see increases in sales tax across the board, which will particularly hit this country's transport sector, and we have grave concerns about that.

I just wanted to put on record the coalition's objection to the way in which the government is handling these sales tax bills. In addition, it is highly irregular for a government to act in this fashion, to deceive the people by not telling them what its sales tax plans are and then race these bills through parliament. They are totally objectionable and the opposition feels they should not be agreed to.
I note that my colleague Senator Watson has come into the chamber. I know he has particular perspicacious concerns to raise and I shall therefore yield the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering message No. 106 and the request that was made by the Senate to the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives considered the Senate's message, which requested the House to make certain amendments. There have been some concessions because the House of Representatives has not made the requested amendments Nos 1, 2 and 5 but has made requested amendments Nos 3 and 4.

PARA.TAB: The opposition intends to stay with its previous strong position and disagree with the government's motion that the Senate not press the amendment. We disagree with that because we believe that that request has to be pursued and returned to the House of Representatives.

If we look at some of the figures, we find that the revenue loss to the government is really quite significant. In terms of winning and losing, it is quite true that the winemakers have received a considerable tax concession in reduced sales tax and increased depreciation allowances for the planting of their vines. But against that scenario, they are concerned that if the Liberal Party presses these amendments and they are successful, the government will threaten or blackmail them with a tax excise proposal.

Under the regime of a tax excise proposal, the government does not have to immediately introduce legislation to support that proposal. There would be no certainty that when that legislation is subsequently introduced in a few months—maybe in 10 months—it will necessarily pass the parliament, unless special deals have been done. They are the sorts of deals the details of which we are trying to extract from the government and those who made the deals with the government last night.

The wine industry has to thank the Liberal Party for its very strong stand. Certainly it would not have got anything had we not taken such a stand. So it is not surprising that, following the deals that have been done, certain pressure is being put upon us to cave in.

Let me explain the significance of the figures. Initially, the sales tax increases were expected to raise $70 million in 1993-94, $95 million in 1994-95 and $105 million in 1995-96. But they are now expected to raise only $17 million in 1993-94 instead of $70 million, and so on. But at the same time the wine industry will be provided with quite generous income tax concessions. We say to the wine industry and others that this could not have been achieved without the benefit of the very strong stance taken by the Liberal Party.

It was unfortunate that the debate was guillotined through the House of Representatives. The Liberal Party achieved some concessions there and we will continue to press our amendments. The government has put a motion before this chamber that the Senate should not press the amendments. We disagree.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter of the wholesale sales tax was last before the chamber, I voted to support the opposition's motion to request the House of Representatives to amend the sales tax bills in order to delete the second tranche of the WST—that is, the one per cent increase in wholesale sales tax which is due to take effect in the middle of 1995. I did so in the hope that something would be done between the time the message left this chamber and the time it reached the House of Representatives. I have always indicated my view on the wholesale sales tax, which is that if the government believes it is the centrepiece of its long-term deficit reduction strategy, it is a matter that we should have regard to.

PARA.TAB: We should have regard to this provision provided the burden does not fall unfairly on certain groups, including people in my own state of Tasmania, families with children, unemployed and others within the community. The burden should not fall unfairly on those people.

It is now known that I have had discussions about these matters, as one would expect, because I represent the state of Tasmania. These discussions have proven to be somewhat fruitful in some areas. However, that raises another question; that is, how this chamber deals with the increase in fuel excise, particularly the increase in fuel excise on bunker fuel. The outcome of that remains to be seen. That is a debate for later.

I was concerned and expressed in this chamber that the tax cuts did not have regard to the principle of horizontal tax equity. In other words, there are a large number of families, particularly one income families, who are battling, who are only just making ends meet and who are paying their way, but they are the ones being neglected. Those people are middle income Australians who are on one income, have one, two, three, four or five children and are paying their way completely.

The tax cuts did not have regard to those people. The tax cuts were given to dual income families without children. They received the same tax cuts as single income families with children. In fact, a dual income family without children received extra tax cuts because of the operation of the tax free threshold. Those are the sorts of things that I have raised here and in other areas.

I believe there is an intention to focus on those issues. I know there is an intention by the government and I have heard that there is an intention by the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens to focus on this issue. The horizontal tax equity question is an area which has been neglected. It is understood that it has been neglected and we have to face up to that.

Secondly, so far as the WST, the wholesale sales tax, increase of one per cent in mid-1995 is concerned, it is important that discussions be held to ensure that the impact of those increases does not harm families with children. In other words, there should be some compensation entered into. That is one of the reasons the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced yesterday that there would be a dollar per child placed into the additional family payments scheme from 1 January 1995. That will be some months before the one per cent wholesale sales tax will come into operation.

It is a matter of concern to me that the government chose to go down the track of indirect taxes as a centre piece of its long-term budget reduction strategy. I can understand the statements that have been made by the opposition in regard to this matter, particularly after it received a pasting by the government during the election campaign about indirect taxes—the GST.

If I were in the opposition's place, I would also feel that way. It might well be that I would also take the attitude that it is taking on this matter. Members of the opposition are saying, `We came clean during the election campaign and you didn't. You can stew in your own juice'. However, I am in a different position now, in that I need to have regard to this question of long-term deficit reduction strategy. I voted in support of the amendment moved by the opposition so that this bill could go back to the House of Representatives and so that further time could be bought, as it were, for the matter to be more maturely considered by all parties, including the government. I now need to reconsider my position, having regard to what has taken place in the meantime.

It has been said previously—and I acknowledge it—that none of this would have been achieved had it not been for the stand taken by the opposition. I acknowledge that straight out. It is quite true. However, in fairness, there has been a readiness by the government to look at things in a more reflective way and to come up with a series of proposals that will ameliorate the effect of the one per cent increase in wholesale sales tax in mid-1995 on persons who can least afford to pay that. This is what the government has done. Under all of those circumstances, it is my intention to vote for the proposition that has been put forward by Senator McMullan.

I make the point, though, that we need to distinguish between this measure and the fuel excise measure that will be before us later today. I will consider my position on that measure as the day goes on, as I have been trying to do over a period. I acknowledge that what the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens have done in respect of that has been important. I also acknowledge the actions of the government, particularly the Prime Minister, in ensuring what I believe will probably be a more reasonable result, having regard to the effect of the measure on persons who will least be able to afford it.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I think it is worth putting a few things on the record, especially for the sake of Western Australia, the state in which the two Greens reside, one of whom happened to be elected to this chamber on the spill-over of Liberal preferences. In newspaper articles this morning the Greens are claiming credit for altering the budget and getting the budget to where it is.

PARA.TAB: At least Senator Margetts had the decency on the Today show this morning to acknowledge that, if it was not for the solid 36 votes that the coalition has in this chamber, the Greens would be irrelevant; they would have been able to do nothing. The position the coalition took the day after the budget was that we would vote against these measures because they would increase sales taxes. The Labor Party said during the election campaign that it would not do that, but we know what happened to that. I am glad that Senator Harradine gave us credit when he said that we were misrepresented during the election campaign. Now that is history.

Senator Chamarette claimed last night just before the adjournment that the Greens had got out of the government a $3 a week increase for the unemployed and an increase of $1 per child in family allowance from January 1995. But by January 1995 who knows who is going to be in government? Senator Chamarette then claims, according to this morning's biased report in the Australian, that this will cost the government about $17 million immediately and $144 million in a full financial year. I believe that the people of Western Australia have to be told what the two Green senators have put at risk by extracting this small measure out of the government. I suppose a $3 rise for the unemployed is something, although $3 does not seem very much.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wouldn't buy a packet of cigarettes.

—That is right; it would not buy a packet of cigarettes. Not having been a smoker since I left school, I would not know the price of a packet of cigarettes. For those who do not have much money, $3 is a lot. But people's jobs are being put in jeopardy. There will be $3 for the unemployed, but they are already unemployed. This increase in sales tax will put a lot more people on the unemployed list or maybe give them a good fright that they are heading that way.

PARA.TAB: The legislation we are concluding debate on now is worth about an extra $1 billion in increased sales tax. If it is cut by $17m—Senator Harradine said that that is not a great amount—in a full year that will amount to $144 million. The revenue from the increased sales tax is all extra; it is not a total bill. So the $144 million will not make a great dent in the whole budget. I am very annoyed that the Greens of Western Australia built up a profile on our solid 36 votes. As I said before, they would have been irrelevant if it were not for our 36 votes that never wavered and never will.

I will give the chamber some figures relating to the jobs that are being put in jeopardy. The transport industry alone—an industry that I know very well—employs 385,000 people directly and provides 2.4 per cent of GDP. How many of those jobs will be lost? I said in the second reading debate that a one per cent increase in wholesale tax does not seem very much, but when you are buying a new prime mover, for instance, to replace an existing one or as an extra one if you are trying to expand, it will cost you nearly $200,000 wholesale. That is an extra $2,000 immediately, then another $2,000 next March. So what will this legislation do to the transport industry?What the Green senators extracted out of the government is minimal compared to what this legislation will do to the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indirect taxes to pay for income tax cuts.

—That is correct. We have a rise of $3 for the unemployed. There is a bill yet to come before the parliament relating to changes in Austudy for 16- and 17-year-olds. It will have the effect of transferring 16- and 17-year-olds from Austudy to family allowance. We will have our day to debate that one, but I know that it will reduce country kids' Austudy allowance—to be family allowance—by $8 a week. I would like to know how the Green senators will vote when that bill comes before the chamber. If they have claimed great victory for getting an increase of $3 a week for the unemployed and an extra $1 in child allowance by 1995, how are they going to deal with that bill?

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, the Greens claim that they are the champions of not only Western Australia but Australia. In relation to the wine tax, they gave certain undertakings to the wine industry in Margaret River, but I think they might have given the industry some false hopes. They have now backed down on that issue. All Western Australians who can hear me this morning should be questioning the Green senators, Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts, as to why, after having led people to believe that they were standing up like this solid opposition over here, they decided to turn around and abandon the people of Western Australia. Maybe it was because of the fear of a double dissolution; I do not know. If we are to have a double dissolution, then let us have it.

Anyhow, the Green senators can explain that to the people of Western Australia. I urge people to question them as to what their motives are in this place. They have certainly put a lot of stable jobs in the transport industry, the mining industry and the rural industry—which provide Australia with the majority of its export income these days—in jeopardy. The government should do something about the unemployed in other ways, rather than giving a paltry $3 a week. The government needs to get the economy going so that jobs can be created.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1993 effectively delays the introduction of last December's parliament-approved Migration Reform Act in that the start up date, which is in place at the moment, is 1 November this year. The amending bill before us will delay that date until September 1994. Rather than giving 10 months for the implementation of the bill passed by the parliament last December, it gives a period of 20 months. An initial part of the reform act which related to the establishment of the Refugee Review Tribunal was implemented on 1 July this year, but all other aspects are to be deferred by this bill until 1 September next year.

PARA.TAB: The bill also introduces some amendments dealing with transitional arrangements which arise because of the delay. These are technical matters relating to definitions of unauthorised boat arrivals and the powers of the Refugee Review Tribunal to consider refugee status review applications made before 1 July 1993. These aspects are not controversial and the coalition has no difficulty in supporting them.

However, the coalition is strongly critical of the main purpose of this bill—that is, the further delay of 10 months in the implementation of the Migration Reform Act. After all, the reform act is an important decision of this parliament, an important reform to migration arrangements. It makes significant changes to the legislative framework which currently underpins our migration program. It changes the regulation of entry to and stay in Australia as well as making changes to the provisions concerning detention and removal of non-citizens who are in Australia unlawfully. We in the Liberal and National parties strongly condemn the government for this further delay.

We believe that there is an urgent need for solutions to the matters that were being addressed in our debate last December—which we thought had been resolved. This urgency continues, yet the government is unable to put a coherent solution before the parliament. The reason why the Migration Reform Act was considered so important last December was its urgency, yet the substance of that urgency is now being delayed by the government for 20 months.

The reasons for deferral have been outlined in a number of informal and then formal meetings with parliamentarians by representatives of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus). There is reference in the evidence of the special hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on Friday, 1 October to a number of briefings that were given to members of the coalition, the Democrats, the Greens and, I presume, the government back bench on this matter. I participated in these briefings. There was not an immediate credibility in the briefings that the coalition received. So our questions persisted. This situation led to the coalition requiring a formal Senate committee hearing on this bill so that the explanations given by the minister's representatives would be clearly in the Hansard.

Appearing at the hearing were the Secretary to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Conybeare; the deputy secretary to the department, Mr Richardson; and representatives from the legislative section of the department and also from the Attorney-General's Department. There were some private, or non-government, witnesses—not least Dr Cronin, whom I very much respect in these matters.

When I went through the several hours of discussion, as recorded in the Hansard of that hearing on 1 October, I saw a similar slowness in the explanations actually coming across to the Senate committee from those representing the minister and the Australian government. For instance, on page 88 of the Hansard record, this question was put by my colleague Senator Short:

I want to know why a bill was drafted, passed by this parliament with bipartisan support, with a start-up date almost a year down the track and then subsequently found to be so badly flawed that it needs so much drafting and everything else flowing from that that it will be almost another year before its implementation. Perhaps it is a question that I should direct to Attorney-General's.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a slowness of answer to that question. It took another hour at least. Another of my colleagues, Senator Ellison, on the same page of the Hansard, asked this question:
It is true, is it not, that work has been embarked on this regime of reforms since 1989?

As a member of the parliament's Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations at the time when there was major foundational reform of migration law, I remind the Senate that there were 30 meetings. The then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, is in the chamber. He understands the enormous consideration that was given back in 1989. A lot of time has passed. It is clear from this hearing on 1 October—and we must acknowledge it in this debate—that the government does not have a coherent approach to this, even now; and it is being put out yet another 10 months. Senator Ellison continued:

You brought in that code in 1989 with the review of decisions, which is what we are looking at here. So, in effect, the department has been engaged in an ongoing review of this situation for the last four years.

The present minister, Senator Bolkus, made an announcement yesterday regarding a special arrangement for Cambodian boat people. This announcement has been made before the parliamentary committee has completed its inquiry into detention on the grounds of illegal immigration and arrival in Australia, due in December. We have carts before horses; announcements before reviews have been completed; and a lack of credible coherence from the present minister and from the government. In this context I take up a question asked by my colleague Senator O'Chee at the hearing on 1 October, which appears on page 85 of the Hansard:
Can you table a list of the further amendments that you require to help this committee?

That was a good question, I put to any member of this Senate, and a question that he had to repeat half an hour later and, yet again, an hour and a half later without getting a satisfactory answer. He was told, `There are about 40 amendments'. He was then told, `Most of them are technical; most of them are typographical'. The question was still put, `But what are the amendments? You have had 10 months since this bill was adopted by the parliament and you are wanting to bring in further amendments but you can't describe what they are'.

PARA.TAB: Apart from being told on several occasions that there are a number of substantial amendments, it is still not clear that the minister or his advisers have a clear view as to whether there are one or two amendments or up to 20 or 40 amendments, and so on. It will only be as we near September next year that we will, I suppose, receive a coherent approach from the present government.

At the hearing on 1 October an insistent question was put by my colleague Senator Short. It appears on page 101 of the Hansard and relates to the one major amendment to this bill that the coalition was foreshadowing. That amendment was to the effect that if the government wants the greater part of the reform act of December 1992 deferred for 10 months, there is one element—the matters that relate to the proposed section 4B, the grounds for judicial review of an immigration decision—that it should at least allow to be on time, on 1 November in two weeks time. What consequences would there be if our foreshadowed amendment were adopted so that this element would actually be on time? This is a matter which is of very real concern to Liberal and National party members and, I understand, to the government.

When that question—the nub of this whole hearing—was put, after a couple of hours of preliminary discussion, the secretary to the department, Mr Conybeare, remained silent. The deputy secretary, Mr Richardson, gave a one sentence answer in which he passed the buck to the legislation officer of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Metcalfe who, on page 101 of the Hansard, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I might just speak briefly and then defer to the expert advice that parliamentary counsel might be able to give you.
A little later, Mr Byles said:
The Office of Parliamentary Counsel has prepared a paper raising some issues. . .

The nub of it is still indirectly given in the couple of pages that followed. I say that to make it clear to the government that we in the opposition are not impressed by this lack of coherence in the government's approach and by the way in which it can account for its views before a responsible Senate committee.

PARA.TAB: It is no wonder that so many members of the Australian public are confused about immigration management by this government when this evidence lies before us, and when there is this 20-month delay for a matter that was regarded as urgent—even by the government. The Australian people want to see an immigration program which has integrity, which is non-discriminatory, fair, sound and well-managed, with accountability for every element of its management. All of those matters are seriously lacking.

I have no alternative but to conclude, along with my colleagues, as a result of the hearing on 1 October—especially in regard to the advice of Dr Cronin, whom I regard as a genuine expert in these matters—that our foreshadowed amendment to bring one element of the act into force on time on 1 November this year will not be integrated, practical or able to be implemented in isolation from the other elements in the act. Even together, there is not a convincing coherence.

On the basis of the rather tardy and incoherent evidence that has been given, the opposition will not proceed with its foreshadowed amendment. Rather, I will move a second reading amendment condemning the government for its mismanagement and incoherence. In the next few days, on behalf of the opposition, I will move a motion to recommend the setting up of a responsible Senate committee inquiry into all parts of the government's handling of immigration in this country. My colleague Senator Short has discussed the terms of such an inquiry quite widely in the community and with other honourable senators. I am concluding those discussions in the next day or so. At one stage I intended to move an amendment to the second reading motion proposing the establishment of a Senate select committee to inquire into the department's management of immigration matters, but instead I will give notice of a motion along those lines on one of the next few sitting days.

The opposition is still concerned that part 4B, which relates to the grounds for judicial review of an immigration decision, has, on Dr Cronin's testimony, been seen as still inadequate to achieve the purposes that the Liberal and National parties would want it to achieve. There is an unsatisfactory legal foundation for this properly building in of the notion of natural justice to the whole procedures of review within the department that would limit the grounds for external judicial review of any immigration decision. We want to see, in the new year, the coherent approach that we are still waiting for after all these months from the government; we want to see that it will be watertight, sound, workable and capable of achieving the objective that we all addressed last December in this debate, as well as now. On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I move:
At the end of the motion, add:

SPEECH.PARA: "but the Senate condemns the Government for its legislative and administrative incompetence in failing to achieve the timetable for implementation of the Migration Reform Act which was determined by the Parliament in December 1992.".

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION LIMITED SALE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 September, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this important bill—the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Limited Sale Bill 1993—even though it relates to only a small entity. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Limited was originally started as a corporation following the end of the Snowy Mountains scheme in 1970. It has been a very successful corporation. It currently has about 240 staff and has completed over 1,700 projects in 54 countries. Eighty per cent of its work has been done offshore. It has an international reputation of the highest standing. This last financial year its turnover was $56 million.

PARA.TAB: The corporation is in a business which has very good opportunities for growth in the future—in other words, selling engineering services out of Australia—particularly since the deterioration of the Australian dollar in recent years. The corporation changed to a company by a government bill in July 1989. At the time, the opposition moved the following amendment to the bill:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should sell the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to the private sector, with the first option to purchase being given to the Corporation's employees".

The coalition agrees 100 per cent with the government in privatising this corporation. We also agree that equity should be offered to the staff of the corporation. The purpose of this bill is to do just that, and that is what is happening now. Apart from a delay in carrying out the privatisation, we welcome the move.

PARA.TAB: There are two important constraints on the sale: the first constraint is that the head office of the corporation must stay in Cooma for at least five years; and the second constraint is that the staff should be offered equity. Again, the coalition supports those constraints on the sale. However, we are critical of how the sale has been managed and the time delay.

The minister announced in March this year that negotiations had commenced with Tinbury Ltd, which is the company set up by some staff members of SMEC. However, since then, no other parties have been allowed to negotiate with the government or even hold a discussion with SMEC staff and we are concerned about that.

Our major concern is the valuation process. Here we have a company which, according to its annual report which came out a couple of weeks ago, has a balance sheet showing net assets of $10.2 million and a profit for the last financial year of $1.1 million. So it is a successful entity. I might add that it has not always been successful. Prior to its new board and its new management being formed in 1989, there was a series of years of substantial losses. The organisation has been turned around in the last few years.

I turn now to the process of selling the corporation. In the absence of a tendering process, one would be forced to conclude that the sale price ought to be of the order of what is shown in the balance sheet. After all, the purpose of the balance sheet is to show the value of the corporation. In other words, the value of this corporation is around $10 million. But we do not know the selling price of the entity. The coalition insists that the government must advise the parliament of the details of the sale price.

The negotiations have been going on for quite some time. It would appear that the purchase vehicle, Tinbury, may be in trouble in raising capital. I did a check with the ASC and in a report submitted to it on 4 June this year it appears that Tinbury has paid-up capital of only $119,000. That is rather minuscule for the vehicle seeking to buy an entity worth of the order of $10 million.

One has to ask whether the staff are having trouble raising the capital. As an outsider looking at the situation, if we assume that Tinbury is having financial trouble, then an alternative would be for the corporation to offer an employee share ownership scheme to the staff. In that way the corporation itself could finance the employees into the entity. In order to do that, one would have to open up for public tender, or certainly public offers of purchase, a significant proportion of the entity to other companies.

We are aware that there are other entities wanting to purchase part of SMEC. I would have thought that perhaps a sensible way for the government to go would have been to offer for sale 51 per cent of the shares by some tendering process with the condition that the other 49 per cent of the shares be offered to the staff through an employee share ownership scheme.

The corporation has had a good board since the change in 1989. As I said earlier, because of the change in profitability and because there is an effective board, I wonder whether the government has sought the advice of that board to seek a practical business solution for the privatisation of this entity. Consequently, I ask the minister whether the board has been involved in the sale and whether the advice of the board has been sought and acted upon.

I do not want to be seen to be critical of the staff of this corporation. Quite the contrary. I want to applaud them for what they have done. We have a responsibility to the parliament to ensure that the privatisation is carried out properly and the government gets a fair value for this asset. We wish the staff success in the future. Because of these concerns, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
", but the Senate is of the view that any sale of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation should not undervalue this Commonwealth asset".

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL (No. 1) 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated at the second reading stage that I would be moving three amendments to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) and the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2). Two of the amendments that I foreshadowed are relevant to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1). The first is a request that the bill be split in order that it be put in a clearly constitutional form. I do not want to waste the time of the chamber by reiterating an argument that has now been put several times. I simply say that the opposition remains concerned that advice from leading constitutional lawyers in this country is that there is a very serious doubt as to whether this bill would stand challenge in the High Court. It is our view that it is the responsibility of government to put its legislation in clearly unambiguous constitutional form. The deficiency could be very easily rectified and the government should, even at this late stage, do that.

PARA.TAB: That it is so easy is demonstrated by the detail of our amendment, which sets out for the government how it could split the bill to be clearly constitutional. The amendment is quite long. I am not sure whether my colleague Senator Short circulated it when the bill was last before the Senate, before he was taken overseas on parliamentary business.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments have not been circulated, Senator Hill.

—Perhaps I will summarise the amendment. The argument is very familiar to the Senate; it is that the bill be divided into four separate bills. Firstly, there would be a bill for an act to amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 in relation to fringe benefits. Most of that, I think, is going to be withdrawn; nevertheless, to separate what remains of the fringe benefits area is constitutionally important. Secondly, there would be a bill for an act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 in relation to the taxation of payments in lieu of annual leave and long service leave. Thirdly, there would be a bill for an act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 in relation to the taxation of credit unions. Fourthly, there would be a bill for an act to amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 in relation to Medicare levy low income thresholds.

PARA.TAB: In summary, our advice is that this bill can be put in constitutional form by splitting it into four separate bills. We are therefore requesting that the chamber do that—not to delay things, because it could be voted on in correct form today; so there is no delay at all. To be quite fair to my friend Senator Spindler from the Australian Democrats, because I think there might have been some little communication breakdown, his position was that he would have liked to have supported our second reading amendment—

TALK.START.PARA: —The first one.

—Yesterday's, on the first bill—correct—because that was the position he argued before and that was his position on the committee. However, he has said to me that at this stage, the committee stage, the Democrats would not be inclined to support the request. So, in other words, they support the principle and they still would have preferred to see the government put the bill in constitutional form, but they will not be voting with us in the committee on this presumably because there is still some element of uncertainty, even if it seems to me there is really not because the government could take it out and split it exactly as we have said and have it back here within a matter of a couple of hours. So there would be no loss of time at all.

PARA.TAB: But if I understand the Democrats' position correctly, that is it, and if I do not, Senator Kernot will no doubt correct me. So I will move the amendment. There is some detail that follows which I will now circulate but it is purely detail as to the names of the separate bills and matters of a technical nature not affecting the substance at all. I move:

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate on this amendment of Senator Hill's I am not going to detain the chamber long, as Senator Hill did not, because they are issues we have gone over on a number of occasions in this chamber. It is a very long bow that the opposition is drawing in its conclusion concerning the constitutionality of these provisions and, were it to be correct, it would have major implications for almost every tax bill that we have passed since Federation. That is not to say that it is impossible; sometimes things do occur that have implications for a whole lot of bills in the past and where an assumption has been made that is incorrect. Simply because it is different to all the prevailing interpretation this century does not make it wrong. But the government is firmly of the view that the balance of evidence strongly supports the view that this is a constitutional means of proceeding.

PARA.TAB: We understand the argument about whether the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) should be the test bill. That is a separate question and I understand the concern about that. I think that is the appropriate way to go. That is a matter of some contention. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

(1) Clause 35, page 13, paragraph (a), lines 36 to 38, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

(ii)bona fide redundancy amounts, early retirement scheme amounts and invalidity amounts, paid on or after 18 August 1993;';''.

PARA.TAB: (2)Clause 35, page 14, line 12, insert the following definition: "`annual leave' has the same meaning as in section 26AC;
(3) Clause 37, page 15, after proposed subparagraph (a) (i) of the definition of ``eligible assessable income'', insert the following subparagraph:

``(ia)unused annual leave, or unused annual leave and a bonus, loading or other additional payment relating to that leave, that accrued to the taxpayer in respect of service before 18 August 1993; or''.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 35 of the bill removes the concessional tax treatment applying to payments for accrued annual leave. The effect of my amendment would be to delete that provision. We have strongly opposed this provision since the bill first appeared following the budget. As a result of political pressure, there were changes in relation to retrospective accrued long service leave, but the government was not prepared to recognise the principle in respect of retrospective accrued annual leave. It is still our view that the concession should remain.

PARA.TAB: We hold very strong views in relation to retrospectivity in tax laws. Annual leave may have been accrued in circumstances where people had a choice, but often they may not have had a choice. They would have understood that they were subject to a certain tax regime. The effect of the government's amendment is to change it retrospectively. We think that that is wrong. Therefore, we intend to continue to press our case by means of this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government actually seeks to repeal the concessional treatment of unused annual leave. This must be questioned on grounds of equity and fairness. For that reason, I support the amendment to remove the retrospective elements from this legislation. At the same time, I acknowledge that the government has had a change of heart about taxing concessionally the long service leave component. In other words, the government's proposals in terms of the long service leave component will only apply as from budget night, 17 August.

PARA.TAB: Naturally, the coalition is concerned that the retrospective element of the tax increase on annual leave was not removed at the same time as the long service leave component was. During the committee stage we will take the opportunity of supporting that amendment to remove the retrospectivity in terms of annual leave. The Liberal and National parties have always upheld the principle that changes in taxation legislation should be prospective and not retrospective.

I urge the government to remember the rationale for these so-called concessions. When, on termination, an employee receives a payment in respect of unused annual leave, the amount received would force most taxpayers into a higher tax bracket. Thus, the taxpayer receiving such amounts would be required to pay tax on the accrued entitlement at a higher rate than would have been the case had leave been taken during their employment. We acknowledge that the top tax rate for individuals has been reduced over the years but, because of bracket creep, taxpayers are coming into higher and higher brackets. Personal tax scales are still based on the theory of a progressive taxation system. As a result of this budget change, in the absence of such a concession many taxpayers with accrued annual leave entitlements will face a higher marginal tax rate in respect of a lump sum payment.

Present entitlements with regard to unused leave are also adequate when one considers the present economic climate. Many employees are being forced to resign with little prospect of another job in the circumstances. They may fall short of a bona fide redundancy and lose out on concession, depending on the circumstances of the business at the time. For that reason, I have a great deal of pleasure in supporting the amendment to remove the retrospective element in terms of the annual leave component put by my colleague Senator Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to support the amendment moved by Senator Hill on this point. There are two questions at hand here: the first relates to the retrospectivity, as Senator Watson pointed out, of the decision to remove concessional treatment of accumulated leave—and I will stick to accumulated leave in this case. The other relates to treating accumulated leave retrospectively dating back to 1978.

PARA.TAB: I believe that leave is accumulated for some compelling reasons at times. As an employer, I have found that out. Families cannot simply take annual leave at a particular time for various reasons. They may not be able to take leave in a seasonal year, or they may be under financial pressure and unable to afford to take holidays at that time. It is recognised by the government and successive governments through the existence of leave loading that generally it is more costly to be on holiday, especially if people go away from home. So there are reasons why people accumulate leave, and I have only mentioned some of them.

Accumulated leave is treated concessionally in the tax system, but I do not believe that that is a reason why people would accumulate leave. I believe that there are pressing needs in relation to accumulated leave.

On another point, I do not believe that the proposed retrospective tax would amount to much. I do not think the government has told us what the difference would be to the tax intake of the government by retrospectively taxing accumulated leave. I am not talking about from here onwards; I am talking about the retrospective angle. I do not have an idea of what sort of figure would be involved. I do not think there would be too much leave accumulated from 1978—that is 15 years ago. I believe that leave would have been taken.

Employers encourage employees to take accumulated leave and not let it sit there for so long because, as wages rise, employers are up for more money in the long run. I know that inflation comes into it, but employers would be up for more money. I doubt that there is much accumulated leave around. If the minister could give me an idea, I would like to know.

I have no problem with the government removing the concessional treatment of accumulated leave and long service leave because I do not know the real reasons why it was treated concessionally in the past, except that it may have been to help the families who had to accumulate their leave rather than take it. I have nothing against taking it away, but I am certainly against taking it retrospectively because, as I say, I believe there is not too much accumulated leave. Those who accumulate leave should all be subject to the tax angle from the day the legislation comes into effect.

The final point I would like to make is that there is still some concessional treatment of accumulated leave in the instance of death. If a person dies while still in the work force, accumulated leave is paid out after the date of death and it is still treated concessionally. Not only is it treated concessionally, but also it is treated as zero. Perhaps the minister could tell us whether he has any ideas to change that because I would certainly be against that sort of thing. It is never a great amount of money at the time.

I know that from experience. Only a few months ago I was cleaning up an estate; it was under $10,000. Of course, it helps the family in that immediate time after the death when they have to pay for the funeral. If they have no income coming in the door, it does help. I would like the government to indicate whether it will leave that concession and also to respond to my other questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Greens will be supporting this amendment because we believe that the removal of the retrospectivity element is essential. It has not been done with leave and we therefore propose to vote for the amendment.

—The aspect of retrospectivity was one which, when it was announced in the budget context, horrified me, to be quite frank. It created a great deal of concern amongst a lot of people with whom I am associated, particularly in the trade union movement. Leaving that aside, I think things have changed since the announcement and the government has had another look at it, but it still leaves this residue of retrospectivity.

PARA.TAB: I intend to vote for the request moved by the opposition. I feel, however, that there is a very good argument for continued concessional treatment. Let us leave aside the retrospectivity, because that matter will now be settled if this measure is adopted and if the House of Representatives accepts the request, and look at the question of concessional treatment.

Take, for example, the armed forces. Many people in the armed forces cannot take their annual leave annually, so it accrues from time to time. One of the pieces of correspondence that I received on this particular measure referred to that fact. It seemed to me that it was a very real case for concessional treatment to be maintained. I think the government ought to look at those things in calmer moments and see whether something could be done in respect of those occupations by virtue of which, in many cases, people are unable to take their annual leave annually.

I have always argued very strongly for people to take their annual leave annually. It has been my view over many years that annual leave was fought for and won so as to ensure that workers had a complete break from work—a consecutive break from work—every year so that they would be renewed and so that they would be able to spend this time with their families and thus meet that obligation as well.

I have done everything to encourage people to take their annual leave within the 12 months it is due, but there are occupations where this cannot take place. I gave the armed forces as an example of one of them. Normally speaking, the armed forces have a policy of requiring annual leave to be taken in the 12 months it is due, but clearly there are circumstances where this may not be possible.

I am not sure now where this letter came from. It was from a spouse of a member of the armed forces. It gave a specific example of where the person was posted and why that person was unable to take annual leave annually. I just ask the government to consider that matter at some future stage. Of course, in this particular bill it may not be able to do so.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding my knowledge of arithmetic, I feel the need to articulate some of the cases for this measure. I think the criticism of it has been overstated and, on a couple of occasions, misplaced. I do not regard this as `retrospective' in any normal understandable sense of the word and I do not regard the amendment as equitable. I would just pursue both those points.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, to answer Senator Panizza's question about the cost: the extra revenue from this measure in 1993-94 will be $80 million. Not all of that will be the product of the retrospectivity, but in the first year we would expect the overwhelming majority of it to be. So we are talking in that order. It is significant. It is not as significant as some of the big picture items we have been talking about in the budget—I do not want to blow it out of proportion—but it is also not chickenfeed. We are talking about quite a lot of money, but we are not talking about billions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Significant to those affected.
—It is significant to those who would otherwise have had the benefit of the expenditure the $80 million might have funded. But I understand; both points are true.

PARA.TAB: I want to pursue this question. I thought, when I heard the debate, that I must have been wrong about what the old system used to be, so I went and checked. My recollection is correct: for low income earners, what we are doing here has always been the case. If a person's marginal tax rate is less than 30c and it changes, it impacts upon that person's accumulated annual leave. This has always happened to low income earners. We are just saying that the same thing should apply to everybody else. Those opposite are up in arms saying, `This is an outrage. What an attack upon the basic principles of equity in the tax system. The upper income people should have to do what the lower income people do'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The principle is all right; don't make it retrospective, that's all.

—Of course, I understand the principle and I do not share Senator Harradine's view about the tax question. But, if a low income earner accumulates a lot of leave and then, before he or she takes that leave, the tax rate on lower income people changes upwards or downwards—but, of course, it has an adverse effect only if it is upwards—that higher rate impacts on that lower income earner in exactly the same way.
—There is no amendment to change that.

—No, but all we are doing in this amendment is applying the same principle to higher income people that the parliament has always applied to lower income people—and I cannot understand the indignation being expressed about our doing it.
—It is the retrospective principle.
—I cannot make my point any clearer.
—We agree with you.

—No, I am saying that what those opposite call `retrospectivity' applies to lower income people. If the parliament today were to say, `What are you doing changing the tax rate?', it would apply to annual leave already accumulated by lower income workers. If someone had 12 weeks leave accumulated and we changed the tax law, the tax rate would apply to those people and they would pay tax on leave that they accumulated when the rate was 20c; if the rate were to go up to 25c, they would pay 25c on it. At the moment the concessional rate is that we do not pay more than 30c.

PARA.TAB: No-one has ever said that what we are proposing for people below that rate is retrospective. It is not, by any normal measure of what the word means. I am not going to try to persuade those opposite. Honourable senators have heard what speakers have said. I understand that honourable senators have considered the matter and formed their view. But I did not want it to pass as if in some way the government is being negligent about the interests of lower income people or working people. I want to make that point very clear. It does have more revenue implications than some thought, without exaggerating it into some new air of crisis which is entirely inappropriate. It is a profound cause of concern to us.

What the House of Representatives will do with the request is a matter which we will decide when it goes there. Essentially, the reason I have spoken at a little more length than I usually would is to say that the government firmly opposes the amendment but, in the interests of expeditious handling, we are not proposing to divide on it.
Requests agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: These requested amendments reflect the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. On balance, they probably improve the bill; even if they do not, they improve its chances of getting passed, which is also important to the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal-National Party coalition will be supporting the government amendments. We recognised that they had a social as well as an economic role. That was important. I think that as a result of these amendments 167 of the 332 credit unions will pay absolutely no tax or will receive a concessional tax treatment. I think that is significant.

PARA.TAB: I would like to take this opportunity to point out that we were most impressed with the evidence provided by representatives of the credit unions—certainly the smaller, community based and church based ones. I pay particular tribute to a former member of the House of Representatives, Mr Vince Martin, who has had a lifetime association with credit unions.

What the government has done, in line with the request from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration after it conducted a hearing into credit unions, has been, essentially, to provide an exemption or concessional tax treatment for the very small and medium sized ones. There was a difficulty, in that in recent times the very large credit unions have been seen to compete very effectively in the marketplace with building societies and banks. That appears to be growing at quite a significant rate. In terms of equity, fairness and ability to compete, I think that about the right sort of balance has been achieved as a result of these measures. We will not satisfy everybody, but that is the nature of politics. Under the circumstances, I think a not unreasonable compromise has been reached.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, could I ask why my amendment is not going first.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because I will concentrate my argument on the principle of mutuality, insisting on subsection (2B) probably clouds that issue. Yet again, I draw the Senate's attention to the arguments that I outlined yesterday—arguments which are shared by many members of the Labor Party and some members of the Liberal Party about the important role that credit unions play in our society. The credit unions are saying that they are not averse to paying tax, but they feel really strongly about losing mutuality. They have suggested that—and this amendment reflects this—we could restructure the legislation by inserting after subsection 2 of section 23G of the principal act the following subsection:

SPEECH.PARA: (2A)All income of an approved credit union in relation to a year of income, that is not interest paid to the credit union by members of the credit union not being companies in respect of loans made to their members is subject to taxation at the rate applicable for the time being to companies after deduction from that income of:
The deductions are then outlined in subparagraphs (a) and (b).

The credit unions are saying that they should pay tax at the corporate rate on their non-exempt income. While this amendment might look to be the same on the face of it, in fact it represents a significant change which will result in a different way of paying the tax that the government is seeking while preserving the principle of mutuality. I think that we should spend a little time to make it possible for credit unions to preserve that important principle.

PARA.TAB: It is important that those who seek finance have a choice. It is important that the services of non-profit cooperatives to their members be retained wherever possible. If we proceed with these amended taxation proposals, we will take away the way in which credit unions enjoy the benefits of mutuality and the benefits which flow on to individual members from that.

As I said yesterday, all one needs to do is buy a share. One does not need to turn up with a long list of one's assets and liabilities in order to enjoy the mutual benefits of belonging to a non-profit cooperative. As we move towards concentration in the banking sphere, we need to preserve the functions and the services for those ordinary Australians who prefer to deal with a credit union for a whole lot of principled reasons. We should not seek to remove that option.

We are saying that the government can have its revenue. It can have the best of both worlds. We might have some difference of opinion over how much revenue is raised here, but it depends on how strongly we feel about the principle of mutuality. Petitions on this matter were lodged today in this parliament. Of the 150,000 signatures on those petitions, 50,016 were under my name, 53,000 were under Senator Hill's name, and I think another 50,000 were under Senator Chamarette's name. People do understand what the flow-on from this measure would be. The credit unions are not seeking to avoid giving the government the revenue; they understand their obligation to do that.

This budget process has brought out of the woodwork every lobbyist to try to stop paying any increased tax at all. I am just saying to the government, `Would you please consider this other proposition because of the benefits that it gives to ordinary Australians?'. The benefits of mutuality really come down to a share in lower fees, or no fees, and a share in the right to get personal loans of below $2,000, which the banks will not look at. It is an appeal to the government to take this money and preserve the principle of mutuality at the same time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support Senator Kernot's amendment and also make an appeal to the government. I am amazed that the government was unable to hear the weight of the argument presented in the inquiry, which was certainly convincing to me, particularly from people from its own side who spelt out the beginning of credit unions within the labour movement as part of its understanding in those days of the importance of social justice. I wonder whether the government really understands what social justice is about and the distinction between social justice and social welfare. There is a very strong line between the two.

PARA.TAB: I want to emphasise that, in terms of mutuality and cooperation among people, the credit union movement has underlined the ability of people to have empowerment in the financial area against the disempowerment that they experience, particularly through the banking system, at present. Of all people, members of the government ought to understand that principle and ought to be supporting people who want to join together in order to find an alternative to the system which they believe delivers to them not justice, but injustice and oppression. This is of critical importance to us and ought to be of critical importance to the government.

During the inquiry I addressed a question to the minister about housing cooperatives. He gave an assurance that this measure would not flow on to groups such as housing cooperatives. I am afraid I really wonder about the government's intention in these areas because housing cooperatives too were formed for the very purpose of empowering people, so that those who have suffered as tenants for years might have a way of taking control over their own lives. I was involved in the formation of a number of those cooperatives in Queensland against incredible opposition from Joh Bjelke-Petersen's National Party government, which could not see any benefit in the cooperative movement. It attached to it such labels as communist, socialist and all the rest. All of us know of those kinds of slogans which were used in the past.

I am also worried about the Industry Commission inquiry into charities which is about to go ahead and which seems to me to be an extension of the same principle—hit at those organisations in the community which independently are delivering services and social justice to the people of Australia. I make the same appeal to the government as Senator Kernot made: think again and do not disempower the people of Australia. The government should allow our amendment to go through and so recover some of the credibility which I believe it will lose if it proceeds with this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The credit union philosophy of self-help, volunteer contribution and community development separates credit unions from other financial institutions and provides a degree of structural differentiation in the financial sector. That is why the Greens are supporting this request.

PARA.TAB: The social policy that the credit unions represent is played out through the credit unions' exemption from tax under section 23G. Even the largest credit unions in Australia are substantially smaller than the smallest bank; the vast majority of credit unions occupy a tiny proportion of the financial sector. While credit unions are small, they provide a significantly different style of financial services to their customers. Their customers are all members who are able to borrow money from their institutions while others are unwilling to lend. We do not believe that the government's proposal and the committee's proposal is needed to differentiate between smaller and larger credit unions.

Credit unions are not-for-profit organisations and their money tends to revolve within the communities in which they operate. This is a very important tenet of regionalism and community development and a very important basis to the Greens' support of credit unions. We will be supporting the Australian Democrats' request, because it will achieve the budgetary aims of the government while protecting and enhancing the mutuality principle, which is so important to the philosophical direction underlying credit unions. I thought we were all about long-term and short-term deficit reduction strategies, and here we have a simple suggestion to save a bit of dough. TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) is of dubious constitutional status. PARA.TAB: The first duty of this Senate is to ensure the constitutional validity of the legislation that it passes, not to put up bills as test bills—bills that will be a tremendous cost to the taxpayer and even an embarrassment to the government. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as Minister representing the Prime Minister and relates to Mabo. They are limited to the extremely unlikely situation of the court finding that the existence of native title in conjunction with some other law—for example, a law relating to fiduciary duty—has had that effect of invalidating the grant in question, and I do not think anybody really believes that there will be any such cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —O'Donoghue was wrong?

PARA.TAB: In the case of post-1975 leases—there is a maximum of only 11 pastoral leases which would seem to give rise to this situation—to the extent that there is any doubt about their validity, they will be the subject, of course, of validation by the proposed legislation. The argument would have to be that the Racial Discrimination Act applies either to require procedural justice which was not delivered or to require compensation at the time which was not paid. It will be a matter, of course, for argument as to whether that is so. But I repeat: it is only in a small number of cases that that situation will arise.

Compensation questions, of course, do arise in relation to valid grants of native title that apply in the future where economic uses of a different kind are authorised by the process that is proposed. —The Leader of the Opposition in this place is clutching at straws. I have not seen the detailed statement in question or the context in which that statement was made. I have only Senator Hill's word for the words that were used—that compensation is payable for past extinguishment of native title. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the government's response to accusations that President Yeltsin has abandoned democracy in Russia by imprisoning his opponents and censoring the mass media?

—A number of reports have been put about in the Australian and international media claiming that recent actions by President Yeltsin dealt a fatal blow to democracy in Russia and signalled a return to totalitarian rule, as well as variations on that theme. I think those reports are very misleading indeed, essentially because they are based on the false assumption that Russia already had some kind of parliamentary constitutional democracy and as a result had something to lose from President Yeltsin's actions.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that the parliament dissolved by President Yeltsin on 21 September was elected in 1990 when Russia was merely the largest administrative region within the Soviet Union and therefore subject to the rule of the Soviet government. Not only was there no thought then of this parliament acquiring a role in the government of Russia as an independent country; but much more importantly, even at the time of its election, the parliament's democratic credentials were extremely compromised by the Soviet Communist Party's manifest manipulation of the preselection and voting procedures. The Russian constitution was an equally discredited relic of Russia's Soviet past. Its obsolescence was highlighted by the fact that the Congress of People's Deputies amended it more than 300 times in the two years that it had the chance to work on it.

As I have already said in the Senate, in the Australian government's view President Yeltsin made a sustained effort to find a workable compromise with the opposition leadership. But once that opposition leadership had resorted to force, he had no option but to respond in kind. Subsequently President Yeltsin imprisoned the leaders of the insurrection and suspended a number of media outlets which openly supported the insurrection. But over the following week he released all but 60 of the 1,200-odd people who were imprisoned, and some of the opposition newspapers are again being published, albeit under new livery. However, a ban does continue to exist on 12 publications and one television program. I certainly share the concerns that have been widely expressed about these bans and I hope they will be lifted very shortly.

The real test of President Yeltsin's credentials—whether it was the case, as it appears, that he was violating the letter of democracy only in order to preserve its spirit—will depend on how quickly and how fully we now see the establishment of constitutional government and a democratic legislature. In this respect it is a very welcome development that President Yeltsin has now reconfirmed that the elections for both chambers of the new parliament will go ahead on 12 December and has welcomed international scrutiny of them. The Australian government will continue to support action which helps Russia to advance down the difficult path toward democracy and a market oriented economy.
