It could probably, technically, be solved.
In view of this obvious confusion in the mind of the Prime Minister, could the minister now explain what is meant by `native title equivalent'?

TALK.START.PARA: —The reference to native title equivalent rather than native title as such is simply an act, I guess, of lawyer's caution in the sense that what is being proposed for the vesting of title in these existing pastoral leases held by Aboriginal people is the re-creation of a native title which has necessarily, as a result of the previous application of the law, been extinguished. If we are re-creating, in a sense, something which was previously there but has been extinguished, as a matter of caution, I guess it is appropriate to call it native title equivalent rather than native title—although that is essentially a matter of lawyers' semantics and that view may not prevail in the final drafting of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: So let me make the point at the outset that there is no difference between the kind of native title that we are talking about at large that might be acquired in respect of presently unalienated crown land and the kind of native title that might be acquired as a result of the conversion of these existing leases. As I said yesterday, the content of just what precisely is involved in native title will necessarily vary according to the context and the circumstances. That was made perfectly clear as early as the release of the government's discussion paper back in June—on page 15, paragraph 2.4. Senator Alston can read that for himself. I will not go through it. The notion of native title is essentially a rather flexible concept, depending on the circumstances.

But what is the situation so far as what I am asked about—the question of inalienability? Is it inalienable or is it not? The bill will not provide for native title to be sold or leased and in that sense it will not be alienable in the same way as ordinary titles are in this country. But there will be a power—and this is set out in paragraph 29 of the legislative outline—for native titleholders to surrender their title to governments if they wish; for example, to facilitate commercial development by having a statutory title issued over part of the land. The new native title equivalent will essentially involve current rights to operate a pastoral lease plus any rights—but no more than that—which are held under the customary law of the native titleholders. It is that that introduces an element of uncertainty as to how much in the way of rights of that kind may in fact exist.

Might I make clear also for the record that the new native title will not be the same as Northern Territory inalienable freehold title which does, of course, have a right of veto over mining associated with it. It will, however, attract the right of negotiation, to be provided by the Commonwealth bill, for all native titleholders when development of their land is proposed. Native title claimants will, under the proposal, be able to apply to either the Federal Court or a recognised state tribunal to have their claims considered. Might I say this further, although Senator Alston did not ask me: the government will be giving further consideration to the possibility of legal assistance to land holders whose land is the subject of native title claim. The bill will provide for conciliation to be available to the courts in considering native title claims, thus hopefully minimising any such legal cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. After the mandatory waffle about flexible concepts, did I understand the minister to say that native title equivalent would not be able to be sold? In other words, did the Prime Minister simply get it wrong when he told the 7.30 Report that it could probably, technically, be sold?

—It depends on the precise nature of the native title that is vested. That is not mandatory waffle, nor is it discretionary waffle. It is just a matter of factual description of the content of native title as it has been described.
—Can it be sold?

—It can be returned to government in circumstances that I mentioned and, in that context, it could be sold to government because government would, no doubt, not be taking it over without some appropriate financial compensation being given. There is a question also of it possibly being surrendered—this was mentioned in the original discussion paper and this is a matter that might be the case. Pursuant to traditional laws and customs it is conceivable that the title in question could be passed on to someone other than the original grantees, if that is consistent—
—Is that selling?
—It is a matter for determination by the courts.
—Are you going to allow sales or not?
—I have described the answer as best I possibly can. This squawking budgerigar opposite is utterly unable to appreciate the fact that we are dealing here—
—Order! Time has expired.
—Okay.
—Mr President, I ask the minister to table the legislative outline from which he was quoting in order that we might all be better informed.
—That is a matter for the minister.
—I have not got a legislative outline in a form that is appropriate for tabling in front of me at this stage.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the minister to the recent government announcement of a major study into shipping through the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait. Can the minister advise the Senate whether the laser airborne depth sounder system, recently developed by the navy in conjunction with BHP Engineering and Vision Systems Ltd, has the potential to assist in such a study? What other proposed applications does the laser airborne depth sounder system have?

—The system to which Senator Foreman referred has substantial applications in providing hydrographic information which could well assist the proposed study. With ingenuity and perseverance, Australia has produced a system that is at the leading edge of technology.

PARA.TAB: This is an Australian success story. The LADS system was developed to address an identified need for an accelerated rate of survey of Australian waters. The need was identified in the 1986 Dibb report and the 1987 white paper. The surveying is required to meet our own and international obligations.

LADS was designed and developed to an experimental stage by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. In 1989 BHP and Vision Systems South Australia were awarded the contract to develop the system to operational status. LADS has now been in operational service with the Royal Australian Navy since February and was formally accepted into service by the navy last month. The LADS project is an excellent example of defence and industry working together to develop a world leading technology.

My understanding is that a number of the charts used by commercial and defence shipping today are based on charts produced by Matthew Flinders about 200 years ago. LADS has the ability to rapidly record accurate, high density and total coverage digital information of coastal waters up to 50 metres in depth. LADS is capable of surveying in excess of 50 square kilometres in an hour. This is up to 10 times faster than the present surface methods. In addition, it can provide a complete, safe coverage of complex and dangerous areas unsuitable for survey by surface vessels.

The system is extremely impressive and it is no wonder that it has been drawn to the attention of the US navy. The US navy oceanographer Admiral Chesborough flew a survey sortie in the LADS aircraft out of Townsville last April. BHP has been funded by the US navy to undertake preliminary studies on a number of applications, including the fitting of LADS to some of the US navy's P3C Orions.

There is considerable potential for LADS throughout the world in areas that have shallow coastal waters. For example, discussions with Indonesian coastal authorities are currently under way. Other regional countries have also expressed an interest.

Clearly, this system offers a variety of applications and opportunities in Australia for the production of accurate and up-to-date charts of the Great Barrier Reef, for oil and gas exploration and for the general safety of those who use Australian waters. Finally, interest can be generated overseas in what is potentially a very good export market.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Now that Sydney has been successful in winning the 2000 Olympics and the federal government has committed itself to supporting the games financially, what measures will be taken to ensure as far as possible that preference will be given to purchasing Australian or Australian-made services and goods with those funds? Will the government have in place a strategic plan to make sure the buck stops here in Australia with the games and that the benefits therefore accrue to Australian business and Australian people?

—When considering this matter, the Senate needs to be conscious of the fact that we are talking about something which is primarily a New South Wales government and a city of Sydney responsibility to which the Commonwealth is contributing. The Commonwealth is not running the games and is not responsible for them.

PARA.TAB: To the extent that the games relate to my portfolio responsibility of administrative services, and the extent to which the Commonwealth would be involved in any purchasing matters, the three principles that govern purchasing policy would apply in that area. They are value for money, open and effective competition and maximising opportunities for local suppliers to compete for government business. Within those principles, any purchasing which we did or over which we had control would be conducted in accordance with our normal purchasing policy.

There will be great benefits for Australian business and employment as a result of this injection of activity. I do not want to get into the argument that appears to be occurring in the New South Wales government about what the budget is or should be or who told the truth about it or who did not; I will not stray into that area. I think there will be a lot of benefits. The Commonwealth will support the games because we wish them to succeed. But we will not be controlling the games, so there will be a limited capacity—there probably should be—for us to determine what happens. But the purchasing policies of the Commonwealth, which are based on those three principles, will govern any influence that we might exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, concerns the Mabo issue. It emanates from various press reports concerning the Prime Minister's statement yesterday.
—What did you say again?
—The question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and relates to yesterday's press reports. Is the minister now listening?
—Yes. I am really nervous, too.

—I would be nervous if I were him. Is it a fact that the only existing title that can currently coexist with native title is mining leases? If so, will the minister please explain the circumstances in which this would occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the basic native title is concerned, that is correct. The coexistence means that some rights may still be perfectly capable of enjoyment. It does not necessarily mean exclusion from the land in question by the holders of the native title during the tenure of the lease, be it for exploration, production or whatever. Native title is not extinguished in the sense that it revives fully, in its full application, whatever that may be, in circumstances once the mining lease has fully expired.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps I should read to Senator Crane paragraph 2.4 of the original discussion draft which actually defines native title. He will appreciate the problem with these sorts of questions. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: The content of native title is to be determined according to the traditional laws and customs of the titleholders.
That is, by the courts. It continues:
But there are some common characteristics. It is inalienable, that is, it cannot be transferred, other than by surrender to the crown or pursuant to traditional laws and customs.
I interpolate that the draft outline to which I referred in an earlier answer, which is at least a semi-public document, made that perfectly clear in paragraph—

TALK.START.PARA: —Table it.
—I am happy to table it. That is as it previously stood. It was circulated widely in September to all relevant groups.
—Not to the coalition.

—The coalition was not showing any interest in the content of the legislation then and it is not now. Paragraph 29 contains a provision about alienation which is a slightly more extended version of exactly what I have just said. I will repeat that sentence:

ANSWER.PARA: It is inalienable, that is to say, it cannot be transferred, other than by surrender to the crown or pursuant to traditional laws and customs. Native title is a legal right that can be protected, where appropriate, by legal action. It may be possessed by a community, group or individual, depending on the content of the traditional laws and customs. It is not frozen as at the time of European settlement.

It is because the content of native title is so variable and contains so many different dimensions that it is impossible to say that it cannot be enjoyed completely during the tenure of a mining grant over native title land. It obviously cannot be enjoyed to the extent that there is a hole in a ground and ore is being dug out with appropriate roads, buildings and everything else associated with it. There may well be many other aspects of the title—hunting across the land and everything else—that are perfectly capable of enjoyment.

TALK.START.PARA: —All other forms of lease extinguish native title.

—Senator Alston, in terms of formal extinguishment, that is correct; nonetheless, there may still be some kinds. Let me give another example. To the extent that there are common law reservations, to the extent that there are statutory reservations, to the extent that there are easements and things of that kind, there may well be some element of native title which has the capability of continued application even though the basic title in question has been extinguished by the operation of the grant of land in question.

PARA.TAB: These are not simple questions. That is why it has taken several months to negotiate this. But they are questions that have been resolved to the satisfaction of all relevant parties. They have been resolved to the satisfaction of the mining industry. They have been resolved to the satisfaction of the pastoralists. They have been resolved to the satisfaction of most state governments and they have been resolved to the satisfaction of the Aboriginal people.

The only people they have not been resolved to the satisfaction of are members of the opposition. Those opposite are standing out there, just as in the Pryor cartoon earlier in the week, like a group of lonely shags on a very lonely rock. Those opposite are by themselves because they have not understood what this process has been about. They have missed the bus. Those opposite are lamenting that fact and they will bear the electoral consequences of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, did you table that document?
—Table the cartoon.
—I will be delighted to table the cartoon.
—No, the other document you referred to.
—I will table that document too.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will give the minister a second chance and I hope that this time he will listen to the question and address it. My question relates to the press reports of yesterday and the Prime Minister's interview. In terms of what has been reported in the Prime Minister's statement, in the Australian Financial Review and elsewhere, do the arrangements for the agreement that has been reached and the proposals as the Prime Minister put them mean that native title will be fully extinguished for all forms of leasehold land, including pastoral, agricultural, conditional purchase, tourism and all other forms of lease other than mining lease?
—I will try to spell it out in words of one syllable. I will really try very hard. Valid grants of title, whether by leasehold or anything else, extinguished native title according to the High Court.
—All forms.

—Yes, Senator Alston, all forms. It appears there may be some room for testing that particular proposition in respect of some forms of title which the High Court was not explicit about. That remains to be seen. But valid grants of land in respect of all forms of title to which the High Court turned its attention in Mabo No. 2 have been extinguished. Whether they have been extinguished absolutely or whether they have been extinguished to the extent of any inconsistency is an issue that remains to be determined by the High Court. That is the language that some of the judges used—`to the extent of any inconsistency'.

PARA.TAB: That was the point of my earlier reference to slivers of rights being capable possibly of some degree of enjoyment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister disowned that last night.

—The Prime Minister did nothing of the kind. I read his transcript very carefully. As far as valid grants are concerned, it has been extinguished and is not capable of re-creation except in the context of the mining situation that we have made very clear.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. What are the objectives of the Indo-China legal cooperation program which falls within the Attorney-General's portfolio? What is the function of the committee which held its inaugural meeting this week?

—Senator Burns's question deals with the relationship between Australia and the rest of the Asian region. It focuses, as did the Attorney-General in his announcement of this program just a few weeks ago, on the trade opportunities, particularly legal service opportunities, between Australia and the rest of our region. As Senator Burns said, that program had its first meeting this week.

PARA.TAB: The objectives of the program go very much to the heart of our trade opportunities, particularly legal service opportunities, within our region. One is, amongst others, to assist the process of legal modernisation in the three Indo-Chinese countries with which this program is concerned; that is, Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. The modernisation that we are talking about is very much related to trade and investment related law. A second objective is to promote legal cooperation between Australia and those three countries in Indo-China. A third is to advance Australia's legal expertise and experience, where appropriate, for the development of legal services, infrastructure and new laws in those countries.

It is an important and innovative program, in that not only does it enhance trade and investment opportunities between Australia and those countries, but, more particularly, it assists Australian lawyers to understand the systems of law, values and legal traditions of those particular countries. It also picks up the trend in those countries—Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia—towards market based economies, and the need for laws to regulate an expanding private sector in those three countries and to define rights and the extent of private involvement in both investment and trade.

The committee's role will be to oversee the program. In doing so, it will also help advance Australia's standing as a model for the development of these new laws and infrastructures in these three countries. This week's meeting was chaired by Ms Elizabeth Nosworthy, a leading Australian commercial lawyer. In order to reflect the diverse support for this program, other members of the committee come from the private sector, from legal academics and business sector representatives and, of course, from government and the Law Council of Australia.

The program has funding to the tune of $670,000 over 3 1/2 years. In pursuing the objectives of the program, AILC will collaborate closely with the re-established International Legal Services Advisory Council, of which Sir Laurence Street is primary member. The committee will be concerned with identifying suitable areas for Australian legal cooperation and will recommend priorities for funding to the Attorney-General. At the same time as recommending those priorities, I think the Attorney-General expects a number of existing government programs to be amongst those to be identified.

This program is important in the continuing expansion of contacts and trade, particularly investment between Australia and Asia. It is particularly important because it goes very much to the foundation of business relationships between this country and the three countries involved. We are talking about setting up basic legal infrastructure in the three countries of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. When we talk about the need for a response in this area, we are talking about the direct interest of Australian business and, of course, those three countries which will be the subject of Australian investment and trade opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to his statement during question time yesterday in which he claimed that compensation payments for Mabo claims will be very small. I further refer the minister to the Prime Minister's interview last night on the 7.30 Report, in which he admitted that compensation could be at least hundreds of millions of dollars. Who is telling the truth?

—My remarks yesterday and those of the Prime Minister last night were both qualified. I said, correctly, that the compensation cost was impossible to quantify at this stage. The Prime Minister equally talked of probably a moderately sized amount, but over a long period. Those qualifications are appropriate. Nobody is in a position to make anything more than a guesstimate. The scope of those guesstimates between informed observers is bound to differ. We cannot know how many, if any, grants would be found invalid by a court. It is very difficult, as I said, to envisage any such grants being found invalid before 1975, but certainly, as the Prime Minister said, there are up to 11 in that category so far as pastoral leases are concerned between 1975 and 1993.

PARA.TAB: Whether compensation will be payable in any of those cases depends on a number of factors which are necessarily unknown at this stage. Who has native title? Where? To what extent? Is the grant in question invalidated because compensation was not paid or because there was some purported procedural unfairness at the time? What amount will be appropriate for loss of native titleholders' rights, including special attachment to the land?

It is entirely possible that the compensation bill will be relatively small. That remains my own view. Certainly it will be spread over a number of years. Neither I nor the Prime Minister was purporting to give definitive answers, as is perfectly clear from the context of each of our remarks. That the quantum of compensation is uncertain should come as no great revelation to the opposition or anyone else.

Again referring to the discussion paper back in June, in paragraphs 8.8 to 8.13 of that paper that issue is dealt with in a clear and open and very frank way. Neither I nor the Prime Minister disagrees with the proposition that is contained here, which says that it is `impossible to make a confident estimate of the quantum of compensation payable in relation to past grants'. One's estimate would also have to depend on whether one has in mind compensation per se or the administrative and legal costs of setting up and running the institutions and processes that will be necessary to determine those issues.

Finally, the fact that compensation—which is payable by governments, not by industries; so to that extent it ought not to be a matter of concern for the pastoralists in question—cannot be predicted with certainty is of course no reason at all to shy away from doing what is necessary to provide security for grants and just treatment of native titleholders. While there are some residual areas that necessarily will remain uncertain even with the passage of this legislation—and compensation is manifestly one of those areas—undoubtedly the legislative package will create a great deal more certainty, infinitely more certainty, about the whole operation of the Mabo title exercise than would have been the case had the matter simply been left to be resolved on a case by case basis by the courts. That is why we have gone down the legislative track and that is why there is so much support for this result everywhere else in the Australian community except on the opposition benches.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister whether he is aware of the comments made by the Prime Minister in the 7.30 Report last night. The question was put to him: `Are taxpayers up for a big compensation bill for validating all these leases?'. He answered: `Probably a moderately sized one, but over 20 years. It will only be payable when the leases are validated'.

QUESTION.PARA: The interviewer then asked, `Hundreds of millions of dollars?'. `I would think at least that', replied the Prime Minister. Is the minister aware of that when he says that the Prime Minister did not quantify it last night?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am totally familiar with the transcript. In fact, I heard the interview. I watched opposition members' faces with a great deal of pleasure up in the dining room at Parliament House as they were watching the interview, too, last night. Of course I am familiar with what has been said, and I have given the honourable senator the answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Why is the Commonwealth government seeking to renegotiate the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement for armed service personnel? What progress has been made towards meeting the Commonwealth's objectives in these negotiations, and what benefits are there to the Commonwealth and defence personnel from the new agreement? In particular, will defence receive better housing as a result of a new agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth—state housing agreements for service housing were made between the 1940s and the 1970s. They were appropriate for the time but have become increasingly unsatisfactory for the provision of defence housing. The Commonwealth has been renegotiating these agreements as one of its initiatives to address the longstanding problems with the standard of defence housing. The broad proposal put to the states was for the Commonwealth and the states to share equally the ownership of the existing Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement service houses and the outstanding debt on those houses.

PARA.TAB: I was very pleased to jointly announce with the South Australian Minister for Housing, Mr Greg Crafter, last week that agreement had been reached on terms for renegotiation with South Australia. This agreement now means that the Commonwealth has successfully renegotiated Commonwealth-state housing agreements with all states.

This agreement will bring many benefits to South Australia. The housing activity arising from this renegotiation will have significant economic benefits for South Australia. Over the next three years the Defence Housing Authority plans to spend around $50 million on the purchase of housing, land development and house construction in South Australia. The authority will spend substantial funds improving the houses it acquires from the state. Some of the houses are no longer suitable for defence needs. Over the next three years many will be progressively sold off but, of course, this will be done in an orderly manner.

From the Commonwealth's perspective, the renegotiation of the housing agreement has many benefits. It provides greater control over the management of defence housing, including a more responsive repairs and maintenance service to defence families. It also gives the Defence Housing Authority the flexibility to upgrade housing in the most effective manner. Ownership of the houses means that unsuitable houses can be sold to generate income for replacement dwellings. That will reduce the demand on other sources of funds.

Renegotiation of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement is a win for both the state and the Commonwealth. Certainly from my perspective, the key outcome is that it furthers this government's aim to improve the quality of housing for all service families across Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you create a few jobs? That would help housing.
—Senator Kemp, I stress the important point that that is something the opposition was never prepared to do when it was in government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that there are large numbers of pastoral leases in northern Australia with Aboriginals still living on the properties on Aboriginal reserves or excisions or in Aboriginal communities in towns adjacent to the properties that they originally came from? Will these Aboriginal people now be able to bring claims based on a breach of fiduciary duty or common law with considerable prospects of success? Does it follow that any successful claimants will be entitled to substantial amounts of compensation payable from state governments?
—It is a matter for the courts.

—It is a matter for the courts to determine. As I have said on numerous occasions, I think any claim based on non-Racial Discrimination Act clauses but rather on common law or fiduciary duty or rights of that kind, is highly unlikely to have much chance of success in persuading a court that the grant of the title in question was invalid for the reason that it failed to take into account these duties or common law rights of that kind. It is a matter not for me finally to determine; it is matter ultimately for the High Court to determine, and no doubt it will.

PARA.TAB: On the available advice that I have seen and my own reading of the applicable principles, I do not think there is very much chance at all of those sorts of claims based on those sorts of grounds in fact succeeding. For that reason I do not think the question of compensation in that context is likely to arise.

I think that realistically—and the Prime Minister hinted as much last night—the only claims that are likely to give rise to even the possibility of compensation are those relating to 1975 to 1993 pastoral leases, of which there is a maximum of just 11. There is even a question mark as to how many of them are properly to be regarded as newly granted leases as distinct from renewals or having some element of continuity. It is probably only in relation to those that some sort of prima facie claim could be made based on the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act. Equally again, it is extremely unclear as to whether or not, as I said in answer to a previous question, the High Court would regard in these situations the Racial Discrimination Act as going as far as invalidating the grant in question made during that period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Yesterday the minister admitted to the Senate that if Aboriginals could establish that they had native title, then there may be some chance of a fiduciary claim that would have to be paid by the state governments. If those Aboriginals that we are referring to—
—Aborigines.

—I do not need any assistance, thank you. If those people are now living on the original property that they came from, it would be very easy to establish native title—because they live there, they were born there, their predecessors came from that property and they are still on it. Therefore, that would establish a fiduciary duty, would it not?

—The problem is in Senator Boswell's last sentence. Establishing native title is one thing; establishing a right to exercise that title is something completely different. No, I am sorry, I am not putting that very well. I will put it another way; that was not accurate. To establish a prima facie claim of native title in the sense of long-term association with the land in question is not the same thing—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It is quite clear from the minister's answer that he has no idea what the answer to the question is. Do you think he could take it on notice, go away and get the correct answer before he misleads the Senate further?
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Evans was answering the supplementary question.

—What I am saying is it is perfectly possible to contemplate a situation where a group of Aboriginal people who can establish a longstanding connection with a particular piece of land in question might be able to persuade a court that they did in fact have native title, as it were, to that particular land. But the problem is that that particular native title would have been extinguished in whole or to the extent of its inconsistency with the grant in question by virtue of that other grant having been made.

PARA.TAB: So it is a matter of perhaps people being able to establish a prima facie claim to native title based on all those connections, but to be faced with the situation of it being extinguished. The only right that they would be able to assert under those circumstances would be to argue to a court that the grant that was made over their land purporting to extinguish it was, in fact, invalid because of the Racial Discrimination Act, some principle fiduciary duty or whatever.

It is in relation to that point that I was saying that I do not think most lawyers—and I think most Aboriginal lawyers equally accept the validity of this—would think that there is very much substance to any such claim. At the end of the day, the compensation issue really is not likely to arise in that particular context.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question without notice to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I draw the attention of the minister to a proposed inquiry by the Industry Commission into charitable organisations. Given that the terms of reference are very wide, will the minister give charities a guarantee that they will not lose their current tax deductibility on donations under section 23 and section 78 of the income tax act? Does he agree that the Industry Commission is an inappropriate body to conduct such an inquiry? Will he consider widening the inquiry to make it either a Senate or a joint parliamentary committee inquiry?

—It is interesting that Senator Woodley says the terms of reference of the inquiry are very wide because my advice is that the terms of reference have not been finalised yet. That is advice that I received only briefly, but, so far as I know, that is the case. There are ministerial consultations under way about what those terms of reference will be, so I cannot give any guarantees about that until at least the terms of reference are finalised and after that we will have to see what happens with the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I can tell the Senate that there has been considerable interest in this inquiry. I fully expect that the commission will have a very wide range of views put to it in submissions and public presentations. Honourable senators would know that the commission advertises each inquiry and draws up a list of prospective participants. My understanding is that a large list of individuals and organisations have expressed interest in the inquiry. In fact, some charities have welcomed the inquiry and have expressed their strong desire to put their views to this independent review. It is the independence of the review process that is, in this instance, seen to be the case for it to be conducted by the Industry Commission.

The charity sector of our society and economy receives a large amount of government assistance. It is entirely appropriate that from time to time there should be an independent review about how that money is being spent. The inquiry is likely to explore options for maximising the benefits to be gained from such assistance. For example, it may well lead to enabling a government to provide greater assistance without increases in outlays. It is also important that this inquiry may possibly inform the general public about the direction and effectiveness of their donations to charities and encourage more support. That responds to the second point.

The government does not have any intention of changing the inquiry to a Senate or joint parliamentary committee. Whether that would widen it or narrow it is a matter of judgment but, however Senator Woodley wishes to describe it, the government does not have any intention of doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the minister to the findings of Coroner West regarding the crash of an RAAF Boeing 707 aircraft and his recommendation that the 707 simulator be upgraded so that it can effectively duplicate minimum controlled speed demonstrations which, I believe, are otherwise known as double asymmetric training. I ask the minister: what steps have been taken by the air force to formally notify all air force pilots involved in double asymmetric training, including 707, Hercules and P3C Orion pilots, of the causes of the accident and the procedures to be followed in the future? Exactly when will the 707, Hercules and Orion simulators, which cannot currently be used for double asymmetric training, be upgraded so that the 1991 tragedy in which five air force personnel lost their lives is not repeated?

—Arising out of the board of inquiry, but also reinforced by the coroner in his conclusions earlier this week, the Royal Australian Air Force has instigated full reviews of all operational documents relating to the B707 and all other RAAF transport aircraft. Some documents have already been published, with others approved and awaiting publication and others in final draft format.

PARA.TAB: Corporate knowledge is being retained through the inclusion of relevant information in the documents, such as standard operating procedures and flying instructors' manuals. Additionally, a written review of this accident is being prepared and action has been taken to create accident reviews on video to enhance the corporate memory and to assist in accident prevention.

The coroner also recommended that the B707 flight simulator be upgraded to allow the VMCA or minimum controlled speed demonstrations to be conducted. In that regard, the RAAF aims to issue a request for tender for the supply of a level 5 B707 simulator in early 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was interested to hear the minister's answer, but is it not the case that, following the coroner's report, the double asymmetric training has been stopped? If that is the case, I further ask: given that this training forms part of the routine practising of emergency procedures for the 707, the Hercules and the Orion aircraft, and in particular, given that due to operational requirements Orions regularly fly with one engine shut down to conserve fuel, when will the simulators be upgraded? Or will we be hoping that an Orion with 15 crew on board flying at low speed with one engine shut down will never experience an engine failure in the second engine on that wing, and that the pilots involved would automatically know what to do, despite being unable to practise the emergency—if it is the case that the training has been stopped—either in the air or in a simulator?

—There is always a great deal of debate about double asymmetric training and whether, in fact, the risk in training far outweighs the fact that pilots are likely to react in emergency situations in a different way anyway. This question has troubled not only the Royal Australian Air Force but also many other air forces around the world. Whilst it is true at the moment that the general attitude of the Royal Australian Air Force is not to practise double asymmetric training, the way to do it obviously—
—Only since the report?

—It is something that has been under review for some time. The opportunity to do it in a simulator is far more attractive than to actually do it in practice and that is the method we intend to try to pursue in future.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the government optimistic that the level of support for the proposed native title bill from indigenous leaders, state premiers and industry leaders will enhance the reconciliation process? How will the federal government foster the negotiation process between these groups to facilitate the possibility of regional agreements which have been formalised so effectively in Canada?

—I thank Senator Reynolds for her question—another Mabo one is just what I need at this stage. I thank her because her question does raise one of the most important benefits of the Commonwealth's decision—and that is the consultative process by which it was reached and the contribution the decision will make to the process of reconciliation. The almost universal welcome that the Commonwealth's position has received is a clear indicator of the boost that the decision will give to the cause of reconciliation.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate that opposition members, almost alone in this country—sitting alone on their rock like the shags that they are—appear to be incapable of understanding what has been achieved and of recognising that achievement. Even Jeff Kennett, the Premier of Victoria, not our greatest fan, has recognised the importance of this agreement. Victoria supports, he says, the `general thrust' of the proposal. `The time has come,' he says, `for all groups to ensure that they are not trapped in a partisan corner at the expense of that general good. He is not alone in that view, as I have already indicated. A number of other state and territory leaders have welcomed the agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think the Minister is reading from the wrong brief. This question was: how would the process foster regional agreements on the Canadian model?

—It was, but we are talking about the reconciliation process and, in particular, the role of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in that particular context but also in the more general context that has now been created by the successful agreement on this particular legislation—agreement reached with no help whatsoever from you lot, but with a lot of help and support from many other groups in this country who I am recording now as to the contribution they have made. That support has been given to us. A contribution of an active and useful kind has been made to the negotiation process by pastoralists, mining industry people and, of course, the Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth's response to this whole issue obviously will not be confined just simply to this Mabo package of legislation. The land issue, the dispossession issue and the need to bring certainty and clarity, so far as is humanly possible, into the situation created at last by the High Court all have to be addressed, and are being addressed in this particular context. But we need to go beyond them. The High Court's decision did raise broader issues. The land acquisition initiative that we are now talking about in the context of the Mabo legislation is the first part of that process of addressing the needs of the Aboriginal people whose native title was extinguished a long time ago.

We maintain our commitment to properly addressing these issues and also issues that can be and have been raised in the context of the treatment of Aboriginal people or native people elsewhere, including Canada. We maintain our commitment to properly addressing these issues in consultation with Aboriginal people, and in particular through the broader community in the way that we are now doing through the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, on which Senator Reynolds and others in the government have been playing a significant role.

I would suggest, finally, that the time has come for opposition senators to put aside some of this petty minded points scoring that they continue to go on with in this particular case. The time has come for them to make an active contribution, showing in the process that they are to be regarded as an alternative government—which they certainly have not shown much of in recent months—and actually contribute in all the ways I have suggested to taking further the process of reconciliation with the Aboriginal people that has manifestly got off to such a flying start with this agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister will be aware that when cabinet made a decision in relation to the Wik claim, it was put forward that negotiations should occur between the state government, Comalco and indeed this government and indigenous people on Cape York. In view of the high priority that the Prime Minister has given and demonstrated in dealing with resolution of the native title bill, could the minister report to the Senate on the progress being made in that negotiation process on Cape York?

—I think we really have now exhausted the range of my brief on that issue. I am not going to stick my chin out on what the next step might be in the Cape York situation without taking some further advice on it. I will do that and give Senator Reynolds a considered answer.

—I also address a question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. If he is tired of answering Mabo questions, perhaps on this occasion he could direct this one to Senator Collins. On behalf of my Aboriginal constituents, I ask: where Aboriginal people who own or acquire a pastoral lease convert their holding to native title, what will be the financial commitment of the government to those Aboriginal owners to provide ongoing operating capital at taxpayers' expense, particularly as conventional mortgages will not be available? Will this also be in the order of hundreds of millions of dollars?

—That is a question that simply has not been addressed, to my knowledge, and certainly not resolved. I guess in the first instance it is a matter of the Aboriginal people making a judgment as to whether they think they would be better off under the existing regimes that are applicable to pastoral leases or consolidating and making permanent their occupancy and the recognition of that occupancy through native title purposes.

PARA.TAB: Whether there is some further assistance rendered to them in a way that is part of the kinds of packages we have just been talking about that will continue to be necessary for the assistance and support of Aboriginal people is a matter that does need to be resolved, and no doubt it will be resolved through an appropriate process of consultation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Is it a fact that the land management costs have blown out beyond the capacity of the government at the moment in the experience of the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Rights Act? What funding have federal government agencies and the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account provided to date for the purchase and operation of Aboriginal pastoral properties or pastoral properties already converted to Aboriginal land?
—I ask Senator Tambling to put that question on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to questions without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), the Leader of the National Party in the Senate (Senator Boswell) and Senators Alston, Crane, Ellison, Reynolds and Tambling this day relating to native title.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we have seen an absolutely appalling display of ignorance—whether calculated or otherwise is hard to tell. I think the high watermark of it was when Senator Gareth Evans was asked whether he was aware that on the 7.30 Report the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had actually mentioned hundreds of millions of dollars. Of course, he was at great pains to suggest that he had been watching it and, therefore, presumably, he had a word perfect recollection of all that was said.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that he was asked in an earlier question about the concept of pastoral leases and whether they absolutely extinguished native title. He said that this is a matter for determination by the High Court and that there are two possible options, one being that it does extinguish it permanently and the other being that it does it only to the extent of the inconsistency. He clearly did not even hear last night the following comments of Mr Keating to Paul Lyneham:

SPEECH.PARA: Well what I said to the Aboriginal people I negotiated with last week, look, I will take to Cabinet the notion that, there are two notions, that a pastoral lease extinguishes Native Title absolutely, or a pastoral lease extinguishes Native Title to the extent that it is inconsistent with Native Title. That's what they asked me to take to Cabinet. This did introduce for some pastoralists some uncertainty, although, in fact the primacy of their lease was 100 per cent protected. But to remove it, the Aboriginal people made a judgment, really how much is in this for us, how many of these thin sliver of rights, of uncertain rights, would we actually get? And given that the Government then last night gave them a different offer to turn many pastoral leases owned by them into a form of Native Title . . .

In other words, what the Prime Minister was confirming was that the Aboriginal negotiators had clearly chosen not to have the question left open. In other words, the government had made a decision to go down the former path, that pastoral leases extinguish native title absolutely.

PARA.TAB: Yet we have this minister coming in here and rabbiting on, completely oblivious to all that was said by his Prime Minister last night. All I can think of is that, since that time, he has been far too busy on the phone, probably ringing his buddy, Ali Alatas, the foreign minister of Indonesia, or his good friend Yasser Arafat, to check on latest developments in the Middle East, or perhaps his old mate Boutros Boutros-Ghali, or even Warren Christopher—or whoever else one calls if one wants to make sure that one's job application for Secretary-General to the UN is being properly processed, or perhaps simply to find out how one gets one's deposit back on a failed application for a Nobel Peace Prize.

The fact is that what we got was an appalling litany of inconsistencies from this minister. I refer in particular to the answer that he gave me. If ever there was an example of waffle, this is it. He was asked whether or not one can sell if it is native title equivalent. His answer—this is classic talk—

TALK.START.PARA: —Bigglespeak.
—Bigglespeak, that will do. He answered:

SPEECH.PARA: If we are recreating, in a sense, something which was previously there but has been extinguished, as a matter of caution, I guess it is appropriate to call it native title equivalent rather than native title—although that is essentially a matter of lawyer's semantics and that view may not prevail in the final drafting of the legislation.
In other words, he has no idea what the government's current position is in relation to that, although later on he said what will be spelt out in the legislation. Then he said:
. . . the content of just what precisely is involved in native title will necessarily vary according to the context and the circumstances.
Again, classic waffle. The point is whether or not it is inalienable. What he said was:
. . . there will be a power . . . for native titleholders to surrender their title to governments if they wish; for example, to facilitate commercial development. . .

Clearly, that means that, if they want to flog the land, they surrender the title to the government, the government reissues the title to those purchasers and the purchasers hand over the money to the native titleholders. In other words, they have sold the land—whether or not the minister technically describes it in that way. Then he went on to say:

The new native title equivalent will essentially involve current rights to operate a pastoral lease plus any rights—but no more than that—which are held under the customary law of the native titleholders.

In other words, under customary law for native titleholders, they cannot alienate it. They cannot surrender it to the Commonwealth and pass it on and get their money through the back door. In other words, they cannot sell it commercially. Clearly, therefore, if we are being told, on the one hand, that it is inalienable and they cannot sell it why, on the other hand, were we being told by the Prime Minister that they can?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans was asked the No. 1 question of the day on the point that Ms O'Donoghue made last night; I refer to point 7 in her statement which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Compensation will be payable for past extinguishments of native title. Compensation will be on just terms and there will be no "cap" on the compensation payable.

Senator Evans was asked a simple question: does this mean we can go back to 1788? And what happened? He went round and round the question and did not give us an answer. To me, that means that any extinguishment since 1788 has to be claimable. That means that all Sydney and Melbourne can be claimable. It is simple—and it has no cap.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody is listening to you.
—Later I will read the minister's answer as it appears in Hansard. He certainly did not answer that point. Ms O'Donoghue went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Additional funding will be provided to prescribed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations to assist native title holders in the making of claims.
The next point she made was:

The legislation will contain provision for a national land acquisition and management fund, especially to meet the land needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples who are unable to benefit from the Mabo decision.

That refers to those who live in places where they are unable to claim. If we marry that with point 7—and no-one has told me that I am wrong on point 7; certainly, Senator Evans did not answer it—any claim is open, since 1788, and it is uncapped.

PARA.TAB: Why did Ms O'Donoghue put out this statement? Is she looking through rose-coloured glasses or has she read more into the legislation than has the Prime Minister? After all, the legislation is right in front of us. There has to be a reason why the head of ATSIC puts out a statement like that. All the questions answered today have not mentioned anything about it.

Senator Gareth Evans mentioned earlier how good this government is for coming up with this situation. He claimed that it had been praised by the mining industry, Aboriginals, church groups and the like, but Lauchlan McIntosh of the mining industry certainly did not confirm what was said. Furthermore, I doubt whether the farming industry agreed with what the minister read into the statement. Certainly the major group of people that this government did not confer with was the taxpayers. The open-ended system for claims was not mentioned in the last election campaign. I do not know whether it will be $10 billion, $20 billion or $30 billion, but this government has opened up a bankcard without any limit. Senator Collins can giggle as much as he wants, but that is a fact. There is no cap. If Ms O'Donoghue is wrong in saying that there is no cap, why does Senator Gareth Evans or someone else not say so?

The fourth point in the paper says that where pastoral leases have been acquired or are acquired by Aboriginal people, under the legislation the Aboriginal lessees will be able to convert pastoral leases into native title where it can be shown that native title would have existed but for the lease. That is the agenda of this government and it is the agenda of a lot of people to wipe out the Kimberleys in WA.

Senator Collins can giggle as much as he likes, but the point is that a lot of stations are being bought out with ATSIC money, which is taxpayers' money. Under this system the land can then be converted to native title and the pastoral industry will be extinguished from that place forever. That is part of the agenda of this government, and the previous defeated, disgraced Labor government of Western Australia had the same idea. If this proposed legislation sees the light of day, it will let that happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Alston. It is quite clear from the answers that Senator Gareth Evans gave in this chamber today that the government is asking the Australian taxpayer, the pastoral industry and the mining industry to sign a blank cheque with its proposed Mabo legislation. The government will not show us the legislation. We are being told all sorts of things about it. We are told that it will solve everything from native title problems to a headache. But we are not seeing any clear indication from this government as to the limits of native title or exactly what will be protected or validated and what will not be.

PARA.TAB: In reply to a question from Senator Boswell today, Senator Evans said quite clearly that in northern Queensland and northern Australia Aboriginals are still living on pastoral properties that they have always lived on, and in many cases they are the stock hands or live in the nearby town. They have not lost their link with the land. The pastoralists who hold a lease are not protected by virtue of the validation that will be given to the supposedly 11 leases that have a Racial Discrimination Act problem. They are still open to a common law claim.

The question asked today in question time was: what will be the cost in compensation or what will be the effect on the pastoralists? Senator Evans said, `I can't tell you what the cost will be because we don't know'. Yet the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has been running around saying, `This solves these problems once and for all. This is an historic piece of legislation'. When we ask his minister in this place what will be the consequences of the legislation, how much it will cost us and who is affected, he says, `I don't know'. That is the answer to every question that is put to the minister. It is dreadfully true and I wish it were not.

Senator Gareth Evans was asked by Senator Tambling this afternoon what would be the effect of the conversion by Aboriginal groups of pastoral leases to native title land. He was asked whether it will be necessary for the government to provide the ongoing cost of working capital for those properties.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on whether the property is commercially sound or not, I suppose.
—That may be. But if nobody wants to develop the property, there is no need to have working capital for it. That interjection was inane to say the best and stupid to be more accurate.

PARA.TAB: The problem for the government is that as soon as these pastoral leases get converted to native title, no commercial lender will lend to them because a mortgage over that title would be thoroughly and utterly useless because native title can never be sold. So a mortgagee who takes a mortgage will get absolutely nothing. Nobody will lend to that person. Any necessity for working capital must be met by the taxpayer or directly by the native titleholders. We are talking about people who do not have a lot of money to put together—that is the whole basis of the government saying it needs some sort of social justice package.

So who will fork out for the bill? It will be the taxpayer again. When asked how much it would cost, what answer did we get from Senator Evans? He said, `We don't know. We will have to look. We will have to see what the courts say. It will have to be done on a case by case basis'. He did anything but give a straight answer. The straight answer is that this proposed package of legislation has solved nothing. The government cannot answer any of these burning questions in relation to exactly what will be validated.

Senator Evans sits opposite and shakes his head. He well knows the truth, which is that the Australian public, the pastoral industry, the mining industry and governments, state and federal, are being asked to sign a blank cheque. We deserve to know exactly what the cost will be, otherwise the cost will be years and years of heartache brought on by this government's incompetence and a superficial package which addresses none of the real problems that arise out of Mabo.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that the opposition has chosen to be so confrontationist about this issue. The opposition, with goodwill and good spirit, supported reconciliation. Now, despite the fact that we have reached historic agreement with indigenous people, industry groups, the majority of state governments, the community and the churches, the opposition has just been left behind.

PARA.TAB: I can understand the reaction of those opposite today. They do not know where to go. They have been backed so far into their corner that all they can do is put up their fists and keep arguing in a very aggressive and confrontationist way. When will members of the coalition indicate their position on reconciliation? When will they come forward and indicate when they will start negotiating? Do they understand the word? Can they spell the word? Will they sit down and do some reading about this subject?

People such as Senator McMullan, Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Collins, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and all their backup staff, people who have been negotiating on behalf of indigenous people, and the miners and the pastoralists know the subject area. They have been considering these very complex issues for over 12 months since the High Court brought down this decision. Remember, this decision is not about a Labor government or all those socialists in Canberra, which I am sure is what those opposite are saying to their constituents. This decision has come from the High Court of Australia and it is government responsibility to respond appropriately to the High Court's ruling. Of course there are areas where we cannot quantify and give precise and exact answers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like the GST.

—One could argue that it is a bit like the GST. The other issue that the coalition should start to learn about is the international precedent that has been established. Native title has precedence in other parts of the world. Other countries have learnt to negotiate with their indigenous people. Other countries have not gone broke because their indigenous people have economic independence. Yet extreme, bizarre and emotive statements are being made in Australia. Fortunately, they are coming only from coalition members. Just a few moments ago somebody said, `Even Melbourne and Sydney could be claimed'.
—I said that.
—That does not surprise me, Senator Panizza.
—What did Lois O'Donoghue have to say? She has got an open cheque on it.
—I will ask Senator Gareth Evans whether it is possible to hold some seminars for the coalition to go through on a point by point basis—
—A waste of taxpayers' money.

—I guess it is a waste of taxpayers' money. The most basic point about native title is that it can be extinguished by the Crown. It certainly has been extinguished by the Crown in Sydney and Melbourne for over 200 years. All this threatening talk about one's backyard being up for claim is simply negative confrontation instead of positive negotiation.

—In view of the comments that Senator Reynolds made, I have to say that there is a degree of nervousness in the nation about aspects of all this, and I think that is correct. I must say that a lot of people would become particularly nervous if they read, as I have, certain writings by Professor Reynolds about where he hopes this process will end up. I invite Senator Reynolds to go back and read those writings. She should be aware that those writings are being widely read in the community and that that accounts for a high degree of nervousness about this matter. I put it to Senator Reynolds that there is no question that there is great uncertainty in relation to this issue. I think Senator Gareth Evans in a sense conceded today that there is great uncertainty.

PARA.TAB: It is perfectly appropriate for us to ask certain questions about really fundamental changes in the laws relating to titles in this country. That is the clear role of an opposition. As the government is bringing in legislation to make a fundamental change, I would have thought it not unfair to ask Senator Evans what proportion of the Australian land mass, in the government's assessment, will come under native title. Certainly, that can be answered only on the basis of an estimate. Mr Keating went over to Western Australia and said that he believed some 80 per cent of crown land in Western Australia—a vast amount of this nation—could become subject to native title claims.

I would have thought that to be a perfectly fair question. I would have thought this was a perfectly fair question to ask a government which wanted to be honest and frank with the people—and I know that asking a Labor government to be honest and frank with the Australian people may be asking too much; certainly there is not much precedence for that. We have pressed that question with Senator Evans and we have received no answer whatsoever.

Most Australians are taxpayers. Everyone concedes that compensation is going to be paid. The question is, of course, how much compensation. Is it going to be a matter of millions of dollars, hundreds of millions of dollars or billions of dollars. The taxpayers of Australia are interested in that sort of question. This matter cannot be swept aside in the way that Senator Evans and Mr Keating have been trying to do.

When these questions are asked of Labor ministers, we get the sort of reaction that we got from Senator Evans and Senator Ray yesterday when they called us rednecks. In the old days, rednecks were all Labor voters. Their necks were burnt because they were labouring hard in the fields and the mines. Members of the Labor Party used to respect that sort of person. But the modern Labor Party, full of the tertiary educated people of this world, simply does not care about those people, even though they are the people who will have to be taxed so that compensation can be paid. If the government does not want to ask that question in its party room, the opposition wants to ask it in this chamber because these people will be asked to pay the compensation.

I put to Senator Evans that it is time the government was far more frank about this particular issue and made very clear the amount of land mass involved and the compensation paid. One only has to read the editorial in today's Australian Financial Review to see the great uncertainties. The heading of the editorial is `Mabo deal still leaves uncertainty'. Senator Kernot, who has just voted to increase taxes on all Australian people, allows a budget to go through which will increase taxes on all Australians. I thought Senator Kernot would have been worried about mining developments in Queensland which will help to provide jobs and the compensation.

When one reads these editorials, one finds that, as a result of the statements by the Prime Minister, there is very great uncertainty as to whether major mining developments can be held up in this country and will ultimately not go ahead. Valid questions are being asked, but no answers are forthcoming. If Senator Evans is going to get up and talk, can he concentrate on the facts and not on the abuse?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The more I listen to members of the opposition contributing, as they just have over the past half hour or so, the more deeply and profoundly grateful I am that they have not sought to make any kind of substantive contribution to these negotiations and this policy formulation process. Every time they get up to open their mouths, they make it abundantly and evidently clear that they are profoundly ignorant about, or indifferent to, the basic concepts and principles that underlie this whole debate and the reason why we have gone about trying to craft this particular agreement. Alternatively, they have made it equally abundantly clear that they are not about seeking a positive and constructive solution to this problem of achieving reconciliation with our own original inhabitants; they are simply about making squalid political capital out of what they perceive to be opportunistic possibilities of generating a scaremongering campaign.

PARA.TAB: Members of the opposition claim through their spokesman, their current leader, that they have an open mind on this legislation and that when they see it they will respond accordingly to its substance. They are demonstrating by every word that they utter in this chamber and publicly that their minds are not open at all. They are not approaching this in any constructive spirit of good public policy formulation. They are approaching it in a bitter, negativistic, opportunistic and scavenging frame of mind, determined to score what lousy bit of political capital they think they can among the remaining constituency in this country to whom they think they can appeal, and that is a very diminishing number indeed.

The truth of the matter is that we were faced with both an opportunity and a problem by the Mabo case. When the High Court brought down the Mabo case, we were faced with a marvellous opportunity for the first time in the country's history to achieve a genuine reconciliation with white Australians and black Australians. We were confronted with the opportunity for the first time in our history to redress a fundamental and 200-year-old wrong; that is, the principle of terra nullius. The High Court gave us that opportunity, but at the same time it created one very large problem. It dealt only with a very small corner of the total issue and left many issues unresolved.

Had it not been for the attempt to go down this path of crafting legislation, those outstanding issues could have been resolved only by a process of litigation that would have gone on and on and on and created an enormous degree of uncertainty and problems for investment and everything else, and in the mining and pastoralist industries in the country at large. We sought to reduce that uncertainty—not to get rid of it completely. That is impossible because there are too many unknowns still at the edges, in particular on the question of compensation, for all the reasons I spelt out fully, precisely and frankly when I spoke in question time. There are elements of residual uncertainty which simply are not capable of being resolved by anybody until they are dealt with on case by case basis. That is always the case with compensation issues. They cannot be resolved except on a case by case basis. So of course we cannot tell the opposition now what the quantum is going to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we can tell the opposition, if we get a chance to get a word in, is what the principles will be on which that compensation will be awarded in the few cases to which it is likely to be applicable. What we can tell those opposite about is the processes by which that compensation can be pursued, and also the many processes by which all the necessary balances can be struck between the interests of the Aboriginal people, the interests of other Australians, the interests of the mining industry and the interests of the pastoralist industry.

PARA.TAB: Of course there are issues which are simply unable to be responded to in detail now. Some of those will be perfectly capable of being responded to when the detailed legislation is before the chamber because they go to questions of precise definition, layout, and, clause by clause, processes and procedures. The time to deal with that is at the committee stage of the debate in this place and we will be fully and amply willing to do so at that time.

Necessarily all we can do at this stage is point to the basic principles, the basic themes, the basic issues, that are capable of resolution at this stage and that have been resolved. Some of those issues that have been resolved put to rest immediately some of the scaremongering that has been done in here today. Senator Reynolds answered Senator Panizza. For Senator Panizza to drag out the old chestnut about Sydney or Melbourne or any other built-up residential commercial area anywhere in this country as being subject to claim is just a nonsense. He knows it and he ought to be ashamed of himself for saying it. She said nothing of the kind. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Data-Matching Program

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Employment, Education and Training has presented a report to the Senate today on the data-matching program which the government has instituted in connection with a number of other departments to improve the level of public confidence in the department and the government's capacity to detect and deter fraudulent behaviour. There was enormous growth in computer-based record systems in 1980s. The perceived level of fraud has allowed some sections of the community to argue that government benefits are being directed to places where they should not be. This report indicates that the department has the capacity to recognise fraudulent behaviour and to identify means by which it can be detected.

PARA.TAB: Interestingly enough, this scheme also has the capacity to identify where payments have not been made. That is where people have not been getting moneys that they are entitled to and as a consequence the necessary adjustments have to be made. This program has meant that individual departments have had enormous power to detect incorrect payments, but the various secrecy provisions in legislation up until 1990 restricted information flow between departments.

The 1990-91 budget rectified this situation and enacted the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990. The measures introduced in this legislation included the requirement for most people claiming government assistance to provide tax file numbers as a prerequisite for payment and increased computerised matching of data held by various government agencies. The first data exchange occurred in April 1991. The five government agencies involved were the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services.

As the executive summary of this report indicates, the data-matching program has provided DEET with an effective tool in identifying and stopping fraudulent activity. The department has been able to demonstrate that for an investment of $1.2 million, it has saved just under $1 million and identified a further $6.6 million in debts. The executive summary goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department expects to recover $5 million of this debt over the next 3 years. There is also a significant but unmeasured deterrent to fraud as a result of the Data-matching Program.

PARA.TAB: These substantial savings and debts attest to the success of the Data-matching Program and such results are certain to continue should the program be extended beyond January 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole range of government agencies that this could apply to has meant there has been identification of discrepancies between various measures undertaken and the accuracy of information provided. Therefore, measures have to be taken to protect personal identity. The data involved with the Taxation Office has to be checked against the validity of data actually provided. This has serious privacy implications, and the Privacy Commissioner has had to be involved in regular audits of all the issues raised through this process.

PARA.TAB: This data-matching program clearly demonstrates that DEET is prepared to go to elaborate lengths to successfully protect and stop fraud and, under the watchful eye of the Privacy Commissioner, to examine carefully the information supplied to the individual. However, we cannot say that the same parallel applies when it comes to the department's capacity to enforce agreements to systems. On the one hand, enormous lengths are taken to enforce agreements with individuals; but when it comes to the payment of very large sums of money to states, the same level of attention is not paid to enforcement. The same level of attention is not paid to the capacity of state governments to implement agreements that they have entered into with the Commonwealth.

As we saw recently in Auditor-General's report No. 6 of 1993-94, entitled An audit commentary on aspects of the Commonwealth-state agreements, which was tabled in this parliament, the adequacy of current measures is very questionable indeed. In many cases funds allocated to states have not met the agreements entered into with the Commonwealth. Increasingly, particularly in Victoria, grave concern is being expressed about the level of funding that is going to national equity programs and is not being spent in accordance with the agreements entered into. The whole question of substitution arises in this regard whereby moneys which are provided to the states, and which are supposed to supplement moneys paid by the states for various educational programs, are not being spent effectively in accordance with agreements. There has been a case where Commonwealth moneys are replacing state moneys. (Time expired)
