SPEECH.PARA: SALES TAX (CUSTOMS) (WINE—DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Mr President, the amendments required to give effect to the sales tax changes, that are part of the Government's package for the wine industry announced last week, are contained in this and 2 other accompanying Bills. The package is supported by the Winemakers' Federation of Australia and was designed after lengthy consultation with the wine industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not accept that any of the Bills in this package imposes tax. Nevertheless, it has structured the sales tax Bills so as to put the matter beyond challenge by those who would argue that an increase in a formal rate of tax is an imposition of tax.
For constitutional reasons, sales tax is imposed by 4 Acts. Those Acts impose sales tax to the extent that it is:
a duty of customs;
a duty of excise;
a tax on in situ swimming pools; or
a tax that is none of these.
This Bill modifies the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 to the extent that that Act deals with tax imposed by the Sales Tax Imposition (Customs) Act 1992.

It is proposed to increase the rate of tax on alcoholic wine with an alcohol content greater than 1.15% by volume, from 20% to 31% for a designated period. That period will start on 18 August 1993 and will end on 31 October 1993, or the day before any earlier date which the Assistant Treasurer may announce in a statement laid before the other place. This will ensure business does not encounter problems with having charged the higher rate since the Budget announcement. From 1 November 1993, or any earlier date which the Assistant Treasurer may announce in his statement, the rate will be dropped to 22% rising to 24% on 1 July 1994 and 26% on 1 July 1995. The phasing in from 22% to 26% will allow the industry time to prepare for the changes and the assistance part of the package to take effect.

In line with the changes for alcoholic wine, the rate of tax on low alcohol wine, being wine with an alcohol content of not more than 1.15% by volume, will increase from 10% to 21% for a designated period. That period will be the same as I have just discussed for alcoholic wine. From 1 November 1993, or the date the Assistant Treasurer announces in his statement, the rate will drop to 12% rising to 14% on 1 July 1994 and 16% on 1 July 1995.
The gain to the revenue from this measure is estimated to be $17 million in 1993-94, $30 million in 1994-5 and $40 million in 1995-6.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the Explanatory Memorandum which I now present to the Senate.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the second reading motion. The issues have been canvassed at length in this place and we do not want to unnecessarily take the time of the Senate. There are, however, a few points that should be made. The bills have come back to us, of course, in a different form from that in which they left us a week or so ago. They were then linked with the wholesale sales tax increases, and they have now been separated and changes have been made to them.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the government's handling of this matter has been nothing short of disgraceful. A week or so ago in this place, the Senate passed a resolution opposing the increase in sales tax on wine—and it did so for very good reasons. This in many ways is a fledgling Australian industry, but one with enormous potential as an export industry and with potential to provide jobs in Australia—jobs in an environment, I remind honourable senators, in which we still have nearly a million Australians out of work. It is a good industry; it is a high value added industry; it takes the best of our natural produce and the skills of our producers and creates wealth—and with it, as I said, jobs and all the social benefits that obviously flow from being able to employ more of our people.

The government's attitude to this industry with such wonderful potential was: `Here is an opportunity for us to rip more revenue out of this youthful enterprise'. This was to meet the embarrassment that has really been caused as a result of the lies that went back before the last election. There was no consideration of the consequences to this industry. There was no willingness on the part of the government to listen to industry representatives on what would be the consequence of its intended taxation.

But that is a debate that we have had and I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that this Senate was clear in its majority view that the new tax should not be imposed. The bill therefore went back to the House of Representatives with our message to that effect. It is what occurred after that that is so disgraceful.

In effect, what happened was that the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins—Treasurer for the time being, it would seem—blackmailed the industry, with the support of this government. Together they held a gun at the head of the industry—in fact, a double-barrelled gun—and they were not concerned about the consequences of what they were doing.

Firstly, they said to the industry, `Unless you are prepared to compromise, take what you know is not in the best interests of your industry, we will impose an excise'—with all the destructive effect that that would have on the industry—`and we can impose it without it having to go through the parliament for a year. So we are prepared to put your industry at such risk for a year simply in order to pressure you to our position'. It was nothing short of political blackmail.

Secondly, they said to the industry—the second barrel of their gun—`We do not care how long this process takes', knowing full well that the uncertainty was causing great damage to the industry in the marketplace. As everyone knows, the uncertainty has had a detrimental effect on sales. That was the second threat that they held over the industry—`We do not care how long it takes; we will bring you to heel. We do not care what the consequence will be to the industry. We do not care what the consequence will be to employment. That is not our interest. We are going to beat you whether you like it or not'. It was political blackmail of the worst type.

Not surprisingly, in the end the industry—and when I say `the industry' I mean at least some of the industry leaders—had no alternative but to capitulate and to say that it would accept what has been described as a compromise, even though it knows that it could have a destructive effect upon this vitally important and growing industry.

Those industry leaders were forced to accept this deal, knowing that it was not in the best interests of their industry, because the government threatened them that, if they did not, they would have this excise imposed without the opportunity of parliamentary scrutiny for a year and, furthermore, that the industry would be all but destroyed in the meantime by the uncertainty of the situation that was continuing. It is appalling behaviour by a government to simply try to win a political point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thuggery.

—That is all that it was—political thuggery. The question is: should we on this side of the chamber accept and vote for the compromise—and vote for an agreement that has been entered into under duress? It is put to us that we should do so in order that certainty could quickly prevail. What would that mean? In effect, we would become a party to that thuggery. We would be acknowledging that that is a legitimate part of the political process. We are not going to do that.

PARA.TAB: We are not going to become a party to that type of intolerable government behaviour. We are not going to allow governments to behave in that way towards industry and be seen to be in some way condoning it by our vote. Therefore, we will stand by our position, which was right in principle from day one, that we will oppose this taxation, which is not in the interest of the industry in the narrow term and the national interest in the wider term. We announced immediately after the budget that we would oppose this tax. We were opposed to it then and we remain opposed to it now, even in its so-called compromised form.

We deplore the way that the government has handled this matter. We deplore the fact that the bill has been brought back to us now with the government refusing to acknowledge the wish of this chamber. We deplore the example of political thuggery that this government has entered into in relation to this industry. We deplore the fact that the industry has been forced to its knees by the intolerable behaviour of this government. We are not going to be a party to it. We are not going to vote in any way that could be seen as condoning that type of behaviour. Therefore, I take the opportunity to say that we will stand by our original intention and vote against this tax.

The Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 focuses on implementing some 1993 Federal Election initiatives and initiatives announced in the 1993 Budget. The Bill also provides for some minor policy changes and technical amendments to further improve the effectiveness and efficiency of social security administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the 1993 Federal Election, the Government announced that it would introduce new payment arrangements for long term unemployed clients aged 60 and over, but below pension age. The commitment was made in recognition of the difficulties faced by older unemployed people in the current labour market.

From 20 March 1994, any person aged 60 and over but who has not reached pension age, is unemployed, has been registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service for the last 12 months and who has been receiving income support payments for the last 12 months will be able to claim a Mature Age Allowance. The person will have to be in Australia and satisfy the age pension residency requirement of 10 years qualifying Australian residence. The person's partner might also be qualified to receive a Mature Age Partner Allowance.

Transfer to the new Allowance will be voluntary. Unlike the conditions that apply to Newstart Allowance, a person being paid the Mature Age Allowance will not have to satisfy an activity test nor stay registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service. However, a person might wish to remain registered so as to use any assistance the Commonwealth Employment Service provides. Mature Age Allowance will be paid at age pension rates and subject to the pension income and assets tests. Some of the other main features of the new Allowance are that allowees will have access to the pensioner earnings credit scheme and pensioner tax rebates will also apply.

The Government recognises that the need for the Mature Age Allowance could diminish when the economy recovers. To that end, legislation providing for the Allowance will be subject to a sunset clause of 30 June 1996 after which time no new claims may be lodged. Existing recipients will not be affected. Continuation of the arrangements will be reviewed in 1994-95 in the light of prevailing labour market conditions.

This Bill also gives effect to an election commitment announced by the Prime Minister in Investing in the Nation to provide an incentive for social security allowance recipients and their partners to earn moderate casual or part-time income without automatically affecting their income support payments.

Job Search, Newstart and Sickness Allowance clients being paid at the maximum rate will be able to build up credit of up to $500 that can be offset against income from employment. Couples will be able to build up a maximum credit of $500 each. For a single person, credit will accrue at the rate of $90 a fortnight. Credit for each member of a couple will accrue at $80 a fortnight. The credits will not be transferable between partners.

Credits may be used provided the person's earnings from employment and other income fall below the income test cut-out point for that person for the fortnight in question. For those earning above the cut-out points in a given fortnight, credits may not be accessed but will be "preserved" for up to
13 weeks and can be accessed at a later time.

Newstart Allowance was introduced in July 1991 with the objective of assisting the unemployed, particularly the long term unemployed and those with labour market disadvantages, to return to paid employment and so reduce their dependency on income support.

A requirement of Newstart's implementation was that an interim evaluation report be presented in the 1993-94 Budget context. The report indicated that Newstart has produced some impressive results, including 1.7 million job referrals, over 430,000 placements on labour market programs and 320,000 job placements. As part of the interim evaluation, a post implementation review was conducted. In general, the review found that both staff and clients see Newstart as an improvement on the old arrangements, but officers of the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service felt that the positive aspects could be better used.

The measures to be implemented progressively from September 1993 to September 1994, will reinforce the key objective of the Newstart strategy, namely, to help those on social security payments to maintain their job search efforts and move into jobs. In summary, those measures will:
improve the selection processes for client contacts to ensure the early identification and assessment of clients with labour market disadvantages;
provide more effective case management for all Newstart clients, particularly those with a labour market disadvantage;
enhance compliance and review activity to reinforce client obligations to make genuine efforts to find work, undertake training and generally improve job prospects;
improve client assistance and service delivery; and
improve liaison between the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service.
The implementation of some of these measures requires legislation and the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 provides the first step in doing this.

The Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 provides for the introduction from 1 January 1994 of a $200 Education Entry Payment for Newstart Allowance clients and Job Search Allowance clients under 18 who have been registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service as unemployed for at least 12 months and who enrol in a full-time course of education that is an approved course under the AUSTUDY or ABSTUDY schemes. The payment will assist with the up-front costs of taking up study, such as enrolment fees, purchasing books, student union fees and course fees.

Some people, such as those who have lived or worked overseas, may be entitled to income support from another country. Presently, it is not a general requirement for the grant or continued payment of an Australian pension that people claim or pursue their entitlement from another country, even from countries with which Australia has social security agreements based on shared responsibility. From 20 March 1994, if the Secretary to the Department of Social Security thinks a person or their partner would be entitled to a payment from a specified country, it will be necessary for the person or their partner to take reasonable steps to obtain the maximum payment from that country.
The overall result will be a reduced dependence on Australian social security pensions when payments are also available from specified countries.

The Government is concerned to ensure that the debt recovery provisions set out in the Social Security Act 1991 operate not only efficiently and effectively but with fairness. With those objectives in mind, the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 will amend the Social Security Act 1991 from 1 January 1994 to implement a number of initiatives announced in the 1993 Budget relating to debt recovery.

Currently, Job Search Allowance, Newstart Allowance and Sickness Allowance clients are paid according to the number of days for which they are entitled to payment. If a client does not tell the Department they have started work or received income, any calculation of overpayment begins from the day after this `notifiable event' occurred. Amendments will provide for the calculation of the overpayment to start on the day the notifiable event occurs, rather than the day after and will bring the treatment of overpayments into line with the payment of arrears.

Dual payments, for example, where a client obtains a replacement cheque (on the basis that the original cheque has not been received) but subsequently obtains value for not only the replacement cheque but also the original, will be recoverable in the same way as many other debts, for example, from continuing payments or by garnishee.

The recovery of debts arising from fraudulent negotiation of cheques by a third party will be streamlined by allowing recovery using existing powers under the Social Security Act 1991. This will avoid the need for costly civil action.

The Social Security Act 1991 generally excludes dual entitlement to social security income support and other government income support payments such as compensation and service pension. However, unless a client commits a breach of a provision of the Act or misrepresents their situation, a debt arises only where there are dual social security payments or concurrent payments of a social security payment and a service pension. Amendments will extend the debt recovery provisions to allow recovery of all payments covered by multiple entitlement exclusion provisions, such as AUSTUDY and war widows pensions.

At present, fraudulently obtained payments can only be recovered from the Department of Social Security client who actually received them unless another Departmental client agrees to recovery from their own payment. The Department of Social Security has been criticised by the Courts in a number of cases—specifically, for not taking action against partners who were knowingly involved in payments being fraudulently obtained by Department of Social Security clients.

Amendments will allow a debt to be recovered from another person, usually a partner, where that person has benefited from and been knowingly involved in the fraudulent obtaining of monies by the Department of Social Security client, provided that the involvement of the other person has first been established through criminal proceedings.

The Bill provides for a number of measures concerning the treatment of compensation payments for social security purposes. They are intended, generally, to preserve the integrity and effectiveness of the existing provisions. One of the more significant measures will be to bring within the provisions, lump sum compensation payments whether or not they contain an economic loss component. A great majority of lump sum compensation payments contain economic loss amounts. Those payments are, and will continue to be, covered by the compensation provisions. The so-called 50% rule will remain whereby half the total lump sum will continue to be disregarded for social security entitlement purposes. It is clear, however, that compensation settlements are being entered into such that they avoid, or attempt to avoid, the compensation provisions. The Government has acted and will continue to act to ensure that people who receive compensation payments use them for their support, at least for a reasonable period of time, before calling on the taxpayer funded social security system.

Another important change is to use a new divisor within the statutory formula that deals with the treatment of lump sums. The employees (all persons) Average Weekly Earnings figure is to replace the "all male" figure. The all persons figure is more likely to reflect the level of ordinary wages in the occupational classifications most likely to sustain work related injuries and recognises the fact of women's participation in the workforce and the incidence of motor vehicle accidents across the general population.

Another change will limit the exemption from the provisions dealing with personal sickness and accident insurance policies. Some of these policies pay policy holders an amount less an amount of income support received from the Department of Social Security in the period covered by the policy. It is not acceptable that insurance companies should be able to shift part of their costs in this way onto the taxpayer.

The Bill also, among other things, standardises the treatment of wife pensioners in compensation cases, clarifies the `event' that might give rise to the entitlement to compensation and tackles certain cost-shifting type provisions in State and Territory legislation.

Rent assistance waiting periods were abolished from March 1992 for nearly all eligible clients. However, at present, young people under 18 who have lodged a claim and are qualified for the homeless or independent rates of Job Search Allowance and Sickness Allowance must serve a waiting period of 18 weeks before rent assistance is payable.

This Bill gives effect to the Government's decision to abolish the 18 week waiting period for this latter group from 20 March 1994. This measure will make it easier for these young people to access secure accommodation.

The Government has decided that from 1 January 1994 all secondary school students born after 31 December 1977, apart from those students who attract AUSTUDY paid at the independent or away from home rate or who are homeless, will instead remain within the social security system until they turn 17. Most students will become eligible to attract Family Payment at the new rate that will apply from 1 January 1994 of $123.90 a fortnight for their care giver. Those secondary school students who are homeless will be eligible for Special Benefit. On their 17th birthday, secondary school students will be able to claim AUSTUDY. This Bill gives effect to that decision.

The Department of Social Security issues millions of statutory notices each year to various groups of clients. Most of the notices require clients to notify certain relevant changes to their circumstances and an overpayment results if a client fails to do so. The Social Security Appeals Tribunal (the SSAT) has indicated what it regards as potential technical deficiencies in the Department's notices with the result that the SSAT has found against the Department in many overpayment cases on the grounds that the notices are deficient. Given that the cost implications for the Commonwealth are significant, probably in excess of $50 million per year, it is proposed that prompt legislative action be taken to resolve this problem.

Amendments contained in the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 make it clear that a notice will not be invalid merely because it may fail to specify the manner in which a person must comply with it or because it does not describe itself as a `recipient notification notice' or `recipient statement notice'.

In addition to protecting the revenue, these amendments are important as a matter of equity. Many people responded to these notices and gave the Department information that brought about a reduction in their social security payments. Others ignored the notices and failed to notify the Department of named events or changes in circumstances. It would be unfair to those who did comply with the notices to relieve others from the consequences of their failure to notify.

Since 1991, the powers of the Secretary to the Department of Social Security to waive a debt have been guided by Ministerial Direction in two successive disallowable instruments tabled in and allowed by the Parliament. Only very recently, the Federal Court decided in Riddell v Secretary to the Department of Social Security to set aside the 1991 Ministerial Direction on the grounds that it was invalid and indicated that it would do the same to the 1992 Direction if it came before the Court. This has left decision makers and Tribunals with no guidelines on how to decide if a debt may be waived and, potentially, has significant cost implications for the Commonwealth.

The Bill addresses these problems by amending the Social Security Act 1991 to include the grounds for waiver in the Act itself. One of the grounds in the Act will be more generous than previously. Waiver of a debt will occur where the debt arises solely because of administrative error of the Commonwealth and the money was received in good faith. Previously, it was also necessary that recovery would cause financial hardship before waiver could occur. On the other hand, there will now be no general power to waive because of special circumstances. The circumstances listed in the Bill provide a code for making waiver decisions.

The Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 provides for data-matching between specified agencies so as to detect where two inconsistent payments are made to a person by the same or more than one agency, to detect where inconsistent income data is held about one person by two or more agencies and to detect possible tax evasion.

Ideas for changes or improvements to the Act are constantly being made as a result of the unusually large number of agencies with a direct interest in the Act and the level of scrutiny given by parliamentarians and others. As a result, the Act has been amended on several occasions since its enactment in 1990. The Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 makes further changes to the Act to improve the efficiency and accuracy of data-matching by, among other things, permitting tax file numbers to be used by assistance agencies in discussions with the Australian Taxation Office when following up discrepancies, better clarifying certain definitions and the source of authority for payments of Commonwealth assistance and correcting some minor oversights. However, the most significant change will be to repeal the sunset provision in the Act so as to permit the data-matching program to continue beyond 22 January 1994.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 (the ESOS Act) to strengthen the protection afforded international students' pre-paid fees. The need for this was highlighted by the closure of the Australian Business College in Perth in February 1993. This closure and the absence of money from the special account meant that about 350 overseas students in Australia and up to 100 still off-shore lost moneys totalling up to $2.2 million. Because of the special circumstances of the closure, this loss was made good by a special Commonwealth appropriation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth should not be placed in this situation again. The industry itself must look after its own.

Legislation is also required in the current sittings to address the act's 1 January 1994 sunset clause. There is now little medium term prospect of industry self-regulation or of state and territory regulation replacing Commonwealth regulation. Industry supports continuation of the act.
The bill will strengthen the ESOS act by requiring private education providers:

PARA.TAB: (a) to maintain trust accounts (not just special accounts) for students' pre-paid funds;
(b) to adhere to limits on draw downs from those trust accounts to ensure that if they default there is enough for refunds;
(c) to adhere to more prescriptive refund provisions if they fail to provide the course, or if a student withdraws from the course; and
(d) to be in an industry-run Tuition Assurance Scheme to guarantee that international students receive the courses paid for if a provider defaults.

SPEECH.PARA: Details of the Tuition Assurance Scheme are being developed by a government/industry working group. They will be prescribed in the regulations under the act later this year. The scheme will be run and funded by the industry, although $3.1 million was appropriated in the 1993 Budget to provide Commonwealth financial assistance in its establishment.

Another major amendment will introduce prison penalties for current monetary penalties for certain breaches of the act. This follows from advice from authorities investigating the closure of the Australian Business College in Perth that penalties needed to be stiffened. Increasing the penalties to imprisonment allows the court to impose a monetary penalty in addition to, or instead of, the term of imprisonment in accordance with the formula provided in the Crimes Act 1914.

Additional amendments include: Allowing more flexibility in rolling back the financial regulation sections of the Act in favour of equivalent state and territory arrangements: Providing a sanction when a suspended provider ignores the act's requirement that it not recruit new overseas students: Changing the definition of an `overseas student' so that it clearly excludes those studying on a visitor's visa.

The bill is the product of extensive consultation with the international education industry, including seminars in major capital cities and discussions with the National Consultative Committee on International Education and Training Services. It has also been shaped by the attentions of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, especially the committee's December 1992 report on its Inquiry into the Operation of the ESOS Act.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

The bill complements the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill 1993.

The package of Greens (WA) amendments demands some measure of gain for the pain imposed. For this reason we are attaching three conditions to the bill. The government has said that by making the tax conditional it can achieve real reductions in the lead levels found in petrol. These amendments put this commitment in writing. They use the government's timetable of achieving the goals by 1995. The government at least has to show that it has had an honest try. The second condition says that the government should set emission efficiency and safety standards on new vehicles at a level as high as those set elsewhere. The current levels of lead in petrol are controlled by state law. Maximum lead levels vary between 0.30 grams per litre and 0.84 grams per litre. Lead levels vary to match the standards. Internationally, many European nations set their levels at 1.5 grams per litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 0.15.

—It is 0.15. The US maximum level is 0.026 and will drop to zero by 1995. Japan already sets a zero level for lead. The USEPA did a study with industry that was fully justified and the result was that lead levels could be reduced from 1.1 grams per litre to 0.1 grams per litre at a cost of 0.16c a litre, although this may not include constant octane requirements.

PARA.TAB: The petrol industry in Australia has given a non-justified costing of 2c a litre to drop lead to 0.15 grams per litre, whilst retaining the octane level. There was a round table discussion between industry, the Federal Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, and the states on 29 July, in which it was recommended that New South Wales and Victoria go to 0.2 grams per litre in 1994 and that other states go to 0.3, with all states setting a limit of 0.2 by 1995. Industry would be allowed to drop the octane level by one unit, making the change virtually value neutral.

This was the result the amendment requires. Currently, however, the Commonwealth has no direct powers over lead levels. It remains up to the states to implement the recommendations. The Commonwealth does have persuasive and coercive powers and potential powers for the proposed national EPA. Due to the uncertainty, the amendment will allow evidence that the government has genuinely consistently used its powers to try to attain those goals accepted by both houses in the event that it fails to attain the results. In many respects, the current problem is a result of the fact that cars using leaded petrol are not old; they are pre-1986. In the USA, legislation prohibited lead petrol engines from 1974. This means that its old polluting car fleet is 20, rather than eight, years old.

The initial legislation in the USA was not about lead. It was about emission standards. Lead poisons catalytic converters, so it was banned. We are still far behind the USA in legislating for emission standards. Our standards put hydrocarbons at 0.93 grams per kilometre. Those in the USA are 0.25 grams per kilometre. Our standards for carbon monoxide are 9.3 grams per kilometre. Those of the United States are 2.1. Nitrogen oxides in Australia are 1.93. In the United States, they are 0.62.

The United States EPA is initiating another round of increased standards in 1994 which are liable to be far stricter than the existing ones. State laws, such as the California ultra low emission standards, are stricter still, moving incrementally from total hydrocarbon emission levels of 0.25 grams per millilitre in 1994 to 0.62 in 2003, averaged across the vehicle fleet. Several US states will adopt these standards by 1996.

It also sets standards for other emissions, such as formaldehyde at 0.008 grams per millilitre in methanol vehicles. It demands that two per cent of all vehicles supplied by the manufacturer must have zero emissions by 1998, increasing to 10 per cent by 2003. Similarly, Europe will intensify its standards in 1996 and 1999, at which point they will be among the strictest and they will be comparable with the California ultra low standards.

Auto manufacturers must meet these standards, and they do. Unleaded engines and petrol were available to meet legislated deadlines in the United States of America. The technology will be available to meet new US and European standards. In some cases, such as with the Sarich two-stroke engine, they are already capable of meeting these standards. Where standards were not required, as in Australia with lead, they were not offered. We are paying for that now.

We can duplicate the errors of the past or we can say, `us too', and demand that the best and cleanest technology required and available elsewhere is required here too. This will also have an effect on exports. Where we do not require technology to meet environmental standards, we often do not develop technology that can do so. When other nations do set standards, our exports are often restricted.

The government has no real excuse for not setting standards that can be achieved elsewhere by global industry, such as the automotive industry. It does not cost anything and it is no burden on industry to sell us cars that it is already manufacturing for other markets. It is easier and cheaper to do things the best way from the beginning, rather than trying to fix them later. This is what the second condition will ensure.

In terms of the full package that we are suggesting, in relation to ecologically sustainable cities, the government conducted a major policy study running up to the Earth Summit in 1992. It was called the ecologically sustainable development policy study. It was one of the most expensive policy exercises done in this country with extensive consultation between government, industry and the environment movement and with opportunities for public and academic input over a long period. It was supposed to set the framework for Australian policy into the next century, to set the direction the country would go. The transport working group set forward a number of recommendations after over a year of intensive effort. I therefore urge the chamber to support these requests for amendments to this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be opposing these requests, but not because anybody challenges the underlying objectives of trying to reduce lead levels in petrol, reduce emissions, increase fuel efficiency, et cetera. Nobody, at least on this side, is opposed to pursuing ecologically sustainable cities. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) has put a lot of his time and effort, intellectually and physically, into moving in that direction. PARA.TAB: An important distinction needs to be made between talking about something that is undeniably important and doing something important. Here we have that significant distinction, because there is no question about the importance of the issues which have been brought before us, not just as a result of these requests, but because the issues are inherent in the nature of the bills we are discussing.

I will talk briefly about lead levels. The Commonwealth cannot legislate for lead levels in petrol; it is a state responsibility. I realise the request is trying to come to grips with that difficult question, but that is where the inherent flaw in that part of the amendment lies. It seems to me that seeking to ensure that both houses of parliament acknowledge that the government has put all the pressure on the state governments to pass the necessary legislation is a very strange legislative mechanism. I would not want to be putting all my faith in the way either house of parliament might handle such an issue.

The 0.2 level is one that the government is pursuing anyway, as Senator Margetts knows. I forget whether she referred to it but I know that she is conscious of it from her knowledge in the area as a result of agreements reached at the lead round table. So we are trying to push in that direction, but I do not think this is the way to do it.

There is concern about ADRs for emissions and fuel efficiency. The Australian industry has significant concerns about the rapid implementation of such a proposal. So I think this is the wrong instrument to be pursuing to seek to achieve the fuel efficiency objective. In regard to the ecologically sustainable cities trust fund, there is a profound concern about the idea that we should, in a revenue measure like this, rather arbitrarily establish an amount that should go off to fund such a broadly described objective. An initiative the government is taking in cooperation with the South Australian and New South Wales governments, for example, is the better cities program. For those reasons, put fairly briefly and concisely because we are seeking to get all the areas of legislation passed today, the government will not be supporting this request.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is conceptually attractive but from the Liberal and National parties' point of view the practical application of such conditional prescriptions will cause difficulties in the real world. Also the adjustments are perhaps, in this day and age, theoretical rather than practical in the sense of the costs regarding the rate of change that is expected, which is perhaps greater than we can expect the Australian economy and the Australian people to bear.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

The one thing the so-called true believers did not expect was this government, immediately upon being re-elected—re-elected on lies, I might say—thanking the true believers and then coming in and attacking them with this budget.

It is all right for Senator McMullan to shed crocodile tears; the true believers who thought they could trust the government and believe in it, the government let down in a big way in this budget. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We, of course, are committed very much to the same direction which has been outlined by the Greens. We also share their great concern that the increase in the excise on petroleum and the additional excise on leaded fuel were measures which were in the right direction in terms of the environment but were quite cynically being used by government as an increased source of revenue. We therefore sought to negotiate with government in relation to a package which would seek to address some of the problems which have been outlined by Senator Margetts this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: We feel that the move to set lower levels of lead, while completely justified—and Senator Margetts is absolutely correct in pointing to the zero levels in Japan, to the level of 0.026 grams per litre in America and to similar low levels in many European countries—or the government's approach, which is simply to increase the excise, by themselves are not sufficient. We have sought to go down a somewhat different road, and that is to seek to encourage the government to provide a non-lead alternative to leaded fuels. I would like to outline the agreement which we understand the government has given because we believe that, at least to some extent, it does meet the concerns of the Greens.

Specifically in relation to an alcohol-petrol mix called gasohol, the government has undertaken to provide $25 million over three years, starting in 1994-95, at a rate of $6 million in that year, $8 million in 1995-96 and $11 million in 1996-98 in the form of a bounty which, according to our agreement, is to be paid at the rate of 17.5c per litre. I am still waiting on Senator McMullan to, hopefully, confirm that that might be adjusted to 18c per litre. I hope that he will have a reply to that request by the time I am finished speaking.

That bounty would be paid only on Australian produced alcohol to go into gasohol. It would also be directed towards new production, because this is an industry that we hope to see expand rapidly. That amount would be sufficient in most cases to meet the demand for bounty for those who would get into the industry. If funds were left over, there would be a rollover of funds from one year into the next.

The other condition that will apply to that bounty is that there will be a review of the bounty process at the end of fiscal 1995-96. Hopefully, by that time, if this industry goes as expected, one would see a burgeoning industry which is initially based on waste starch such as the molasses which is left over from sugar refining and one would see expanding into the Australian economy an alternative fuel at the same cost as unleaded fuel which has very considerable advantages. Not only does it remove lead; it reduces the emissions of carbon monoxide—something mentioned by Senator Margetts—nitrogen oxides, unburnt hydrocarbons, substantially reduces the emissions of greenhouse gases and, of course, moves us very substantially towards the establishment of an indigenous renewable fuel industry. That is one of the main mid-term objectives over the next 10 to 15 years.

Honourable senators might have noticed in one of today's newspapers an article saying that, by the year 2005, Australia will only be half as self-sufficient in petroleum as it is today. We have not discovered new petroleum reserves in the last 20 years. It is desperately necessary for this country to make a substantial shift, for economic as well as environmental reasons, to a sustainable fuel.

Given the burgeoning of a new technology which will derive ethanol from cellulose materials, it is quite conceivable that, early in the next century, we could derive all of our transport fuels from renewable sources. This package, which has been agreed to by government, also includes $1.69 million in 1993-94 and $2.25 million in the following year, most of which will be targeted into the remaining technical problems in relation to the derivation of alcohol from cellulosic materials.

The issue of standards for fuel, and in particular for alcohol-petrol mixes, has also been picked up in this agreement. In addition, there is funding of $4 million for a lead education program. That is essential because it is possible that half of those people out there who are now using leaded fuel in pre-1986 cars could immediately make the transition to unleaded fuel. They need to be informed that their make and model of car can make that transition without any change. There are additional sums for the assay of blood lead levels in the community and the development of standards. Also, very importantly, a small amount—half a million dollars 1993-94 and 1994-95—will be provided for an investigation of other devices which are claimed to be suitable for cars otherwise requiring either higher octane or leaded fuel. Even if all of these devices which are claimed to be satisfactory in this regard prove to be worthless, it will be well worth while the government finding that out and informing people. These devices cost some $200 or $300 and, if they are worthless, then people should know about it.

Coming back to the issue of gasohol as an alternative fuel, interestingly, in view of the developments in the last 24 hours in which I have said a great deal about the potential for this burgeoning technology in Australia, I was approached this morning by the Japanese embassy for all information which I have available on this technology. That indicates the vast difference in approach to new technology between Japan on the one hand and this country, where we have had to bludgeon $35 million out of government for a program which carries with it not only the opportunity to address a very significant problem in relation to lead but also the potential to make us self-sufficient and greenhouse gas emission free with respect to transport fuels early in the next century. The Japanese are vitally interested in this technology in Australia to the extent that, within 24 hours, they were on the phone asking for any information which we have available.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter which I sent to Senator McMullan last night outlining the agreement between the Democrats and the government in relation to the matters I have just outlined.
Leave granted.

6. TALK.START.PARA: —In conclusion, I would make two points. Even though these matters do not go specifically to amendments which I am putting, I think they are relevant. We are very concerned, as are I am sure all other honourable senators in this chamber, about the enormous price differential between petrol for country people and city people. We understand that the government is carrying out an investigation into why these differences exist. Once the results of those inquiries are complete, we would urge the government to seek to pass legislation such that country people do not pay any more than city people for petrol.

PARA.TAB: The situation in South Australia is that the South Australian government pays a fuel transport bounty which is supposed to cover the increased cost of transporting fuel into country areas. Nonetheless, country people in South Australia regularly and consistently pay a great deal more for their fuel than city people.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you want them to pay more!

—It is surprising that the opposition cannot differentiate between a uniform price level and what the level happens to be. This is a separate issue from the issue of the excise. We would urge the government, after completing those investigations into the differences between country and city petrol prices, to seek to legislate such that in future country people will not pay more than city people.

PARA.TAB: The final point I would make is that the government, in its agreement with the Democrats, has undertaken to give favourable consideration to further funds being provided in the next budget for lead abatement programs and also for improvement in public transport—two of the matters to which the Greens amendments go. We would seek some assurance from the government that in the next budget both those matters will be attended to. TALK.START.PARA: —I will be reasonably brief. I fully understand why the Greens would want to put forward these amendments because there has to be some justification for their political existence. If it happens to be an environmental cause that they wish to follow, this is one way in which they would do it.

PARA.TAB: However, I will say one thing for the Greens, and particularly Senator Chamarette. Last night she at least acknowledged that the only reason they could negotiate and get any of the deals that they managed to gain from the government was that the opposition took a stance that enabled the Greens to have a base to negotiate from. Had we not taken that stance, there would have been no room for either Senator Chamarette or Senator Margetts to negotiate with the government over the various issues; there would not have been anywhere near enough votes. For the past four or five weeks we have also seen the Democrats negotiate with the government, but I have not seen any acknowledgment from them of the fact that, if it were not for the stance that the coalition had taken, they would not have had the opportunity to negotiate exactly what they were able to from the government.

I would like to comment briefly on the Greens' amendments. I agree wholeheartedly with Senator Watson and with my leader, Senator Hill, that the practicality of putting those somewhat ideological amendments into practice is far too difficult. Also, in line with the other things that the Greens have managed, as they say, to negotiate, the impact of what they wish to do has to be taken fully into account.

I know that when the Greens voted to increase the excise on fuel they did not take into account the fact that the women in our society will be hurt most of all. The women in our society will suffer most. If the Greens look at the last publication of the Australian Automobile Association, they will see that it concludes that the increase in the costs of motoring hurt women more than men. I would have thought that was something that the Greens would have been very conscious of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley should be here to comment on this.

—Perhaps Senator Crowley should be here as, of course, she is very concerned about women. But I know that Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts are very conscious of the effect that this will have on women. I know that this would help the Greens' cause in getting fewer vehicles on the road, but it seems to me to be very unfair that the women in our society should suffer.
—What about Green support for Aboriginal communities? Do they have in mind the cost this will put on Aboriginal communities?
—I agree with Senator Tambling. The cost impact on Aboriginals will be astronomical. In many cases they travel much longer distances because of the remoteness of many of the areas in which they live.

Certainly with regard to the amendments that have been moved by the Greens, although in an ideal world many of them may be beneficial, I do not believe they are practical.

—I want to say a few words at this stage because Senator Coulter made a blatantly untrue statement when he spoke last. I will read his words in Hansard tomorrow, but I think he said that there has been no major find of oil in Australia in the past 20 years. Did Senator Coulter say that?
—That is what today's paper said.

—That is what I heard, and I will read Hansard on that tomorrow. If he did say that, it is blatantly untrue. I can name North Rankin field off the north west coast of Western Australia as one. Virtually the whole of the North West Shelf has been discovered in the past 20 years. Twenty years only takes us back to 1973. That was the year of the big fuel price hike because we were scared throughout the world that we were going to run out of hydrocarbons. PARA.TAB: I have listened to Senator Coulter over the years, and especially over the past few days, talking about the grain alcohol technology that he says Australia should be using instead of the present hydrocarbon fuels that we are using. But that technology has been around since about 1942. It was developed during the last war to try to make up for the fuel shortage in Australia. What are the Western Australia Greens doing about the cost of fuel in Australia? Senator Margetts has gone on record in Western Australia as being the new senator for the Pilbara.
