The second issue is the practical one of whether they will try to keep down one of the massive costs that particularly country people have to bear? I refer to the cost of fuel. Senator Coulter will have to vote for whether he wants to put up fuel prices. Senator Coulter drew our attention to the particular problems of country people, and those people should know that Senator Coulter and his colleagues, by standing with us on this particular issue, can make sure that fuel prices do not continue to rise and do not put a particularly heavy burden on country people. Those are the issues which Senator Coulter and his colleagues must address.

The Australian community will look very closely to see not only whether the Democrats are true to their principles but whether they have some real compassion and concern for the needs of country people, rather than just raising issues which are extraneous to the particular debate which is before the chamber today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The usual performance has been delivered by Senator Kemp. He spends a lot of time coming in here and telling the Democrats what he thinks we ought to be doing and dredges over a few decades of history, trying to find some excuse for his presence in the chamber. The Democrats do not need Senator Kemp to define our direction here.

PARA.TAB: In the first instance, the proposition of an extra 2c levy by this government under the guise of an environmental measure, a health measure—that is, to encourage people to move from leaded petrol to another way of propelling themselves around the countryside—was immediately transparent. It was put forward not for that reason at all but rather as a revenue raising effort, which Senator Margetts and Senator Coulter identified. In fact, the instant it was proposed the Democrats identified that as being inequitable. The people who are driving such vehicles that apparently need to use leaded petrol would have had the choice of modifying their vehicle at great cost, selling a devalued car at a great loss, or meeting the extra imposition. That was the question we immediately addressed.

Senator Coulter, at great personal endeavour, arrived at a situation where those people who had been placed by the government in this iniquitous position would have an alternative. To arrive at that alternative, Senator Coulter has delineated the negotiations which delivered a package which I feel proud to be associated with after Senator Coulter's considerable efforts on it.

The fact is that after those efforts we now have an opportunity for this country to participate in the many benefits that Senator Coulter outlined earlier. Having done that, then looking at the complete package itself, we believe that the primary concern, that of equity for the people so affected, had been addressed. The other concern, providing a path by which lead could be removed from the environment so that it would no longer affect the health of our children, had also been addressed by what Senator Coulter has managed to achieve.

The bonus was the opportunity for further employment in rural and regional Australia for a burgeoning industry, for increased employment and for moving towards a sustainable industry which does not rely on the exploitation of non-renewable resources. Having done that, I think we can honestly say that we have addressed the original problems—and then some.

We are talking about the amendments proposed by Senator Margetts. I feel a little uncomfortable in being required to address all of the amendments as a package. There are particular ones which I want to be associated with very strongly—for example, 4(2)(d), which this is all linked to—and there is consideration of continued operation of amendments. This part seeks to be associated with:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the passage through the Parliament of a bill for an Act to establish an ecologically sustainable cities trust fund for the purpose of implementing an ecologically sustainable transport and urban development policy and for related purposes, being an Act which:

PARA.TAB: (i)implements the recommendations of the Ecologically Sustainable Development Transport Working Group—

SPEECH.PARA: This is the group which considered the very matters which are at the heart of what was purported to be the government's reason for introducing the 2c levy on leaded fuel to start with. That amendment does address that and it achieves those very aims which the government purported to achieve when it introduced its money grab—revenue grab. This is something that is worth supporting and should be endorsed.

PARA.TAB: It is the total package which gives me some trouble because it compromises the government's deficit reduction strategy. But I am prepared to put aside that disquiet for the purposes of endorsing and being seen to encourage the government to see the benefit of such amendments and to consider the merit of addressing such an attitude in future. I think it is very important that we all consider and carefully undertake an attitude change. It would mean that, rather than looking at a situation where we were continually dependent upon the car to such an extent that future governments could trap us as a community into being milch cows for revenue raising without alternatives, we would be liberated from the dependence upon motor vehicle transport as we know it now. That very important part of that amendment is one which needs to be read and read again and, I hope, read again next year in the budget formulation process that the government goes through.

I must emphasise that the strategy of addressing all the problems that were brought about by the 2c money grab on leaded petrol has, in fact, been addressed by the package that was negotiated by Senator Coulter, which is by far the most sensible way to go. These amendments do address that in part. They also express this need to consider the other factors involved in our whole attitude towards transport. For that reason, I will be supporting these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sent away for this article which I have in front of me by Julian Cribb, the science writer of the Australian. I would like to put on the record, because I think it is very important in the context of this debate, that we are talking about an increase in excise on a material which is rapidly being exhausted. Here we have both the Australian Bureau of Resource Sciences and the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd itself saying that, by the year 2000, the import bill will blow out from $4 billion per year by an extra $5 billion—that is, to $9 billion per year; that Australia has only seven years of petroleum reserves left; and that the prospectivity in the basins to which Senator Panizza was referring earlier has been reduced because the discoveries have been less than expected.

PARA.TAB: I think we need to have very clearly in mind—the government, the opposition, everybody—that, as a matter of urgency, we need to move towards a sustainable and renewable source of fuel for environmental and economic reasons. The path which is outlined through, first of all, the substitution of gasohol—10 per cent alcohol in petrol—for lead moves us in the right direction. It is recognised by other nations. In terms of the technology, eight to nine per cent of all the fuel being consumed in the US today—far more than the total consumption of Australia—is alcohol-petrol mixes. There is no problem with the technology. We need to establish it in this country, we have the opportunity to do so, and the package to which the government has fortunately agreed—and I thank it very much for that—moves us in that highly desirable direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments on the various arguments that have been put today. To Senator McMullan, I put a very simple question: why are we prepared to take second best? We know the technology is available in other countries and we know that it can be made available. So, as a parliament, why do we not have the guts to stand up and expect the best from industry, or why do we allow it to give us second best in that technology and available methods?

PARA.TAB: The other point is an economic point in relation to that: if we cannot match United States standards, we will never be ready for export of this particular product—that is, engines and car manufacture—which is supposedly one of the kinds of things that government is expecting. If we are prepared to allow industry to hide behind inadequate processes and standards simply because we do not have the political will to expect and demand better from it, then it is up to the government to look very carefully at its real desire for industry to export. It is part of the integrated strategy that I was talking about.

Interestingly enough, I have heard about costs but nobody—apart from the Democrats, whom I thank for their words of support—is prepared to talk about the benefits accruing to such policies. They are obviously health benefits and environmental benefits, but they are also economic benefits associated with an integrated package of reduced car use and reduced lead production. The social cost of lead poisoning obviously is well known, which is why we are talking about this in such a public way. There are also a great deal of other benefits in medical costs that normally do not become obvious.

As to economic benefits, the government is talking about putting out an employment white paper. What I fear will come out from that kind of white paper is either a scheme for reducing wages and conditions in some regions, and paying people some kind of bounty to exploit in wages and conditions; or make-work schemes in infrastructure that the community or regions have not been necessarily involved with. But here we have the possibility for both employment creation and benefits to the community which will bring other benefits and cut down costs in the future. If we are looking at good employment strategies, why not think about those which have both environmental benefits and equity benefits, as the better cities program was designed to do?

Senator Ferguson said that ideologically sound ideas are too difficult. I think that has been the response from many people over many years. But if the United States can do it, and it is looking at the dollars, why can we not do so? If Japan can cut down emissions and get world best standards in many industries, why can we not do so—and there is a dollar in it for better emissions standards? Therefore, it is not whether or not we choose a good economy or good economic practices, or whether we choose a good environment; we can have both—and it has been clearly demonstrated that we can have both. We can reduce costs in many ways if we think better and not in a narrow way.

I thank the Democrats for their integrated package with relation to ethanol. I believe that this is part of a strategy that governments and communities must build together to find the results—not just blocking, not just pushing through, but working together to try to find the economic, social and environmental answers to the problems we all have to face. We cannot put them off; we cannot pretend they do not exist; and we cannot pretend that dollars are in the way of us achieving them, because they are not.

I commend it to the Senate to consider that if the only thing we measure is immediate dollars then we have missed the point and we have missed both our economic welfare in the long term and our social, environmental and health welfare in the longer term.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in the comments made by Senator Margetts. Given the force of that delivery, I presume that she will be supporting our amendment in terms of diesel excise. Senator Margetts was talking about pollutant fuels. She would be aware of the submission that was provided by the Australian bus and coach industry. It put a very good case for the Senate to reject the excise because of the impact that it would have on the bus and coach industry and in terms of environmental issues.

PARA.TAB: I remind Senator Margetts, to give her time to consider her position regarding the excise, of the fact that buses are far more friendly to the environment. Buses are six times more fuel efficient than passenger vehicles. Buses use lead-free diesel, and diesel results in fewer emissions and fewer greenhouse gases. Fuels which are even more friendly, such as LNG, are being actively trialled across Australia. In terms of congestion, buses are 14 times more efficient in carrying people than is the average car.

Given the eloquence of Senator Margetts's address regarding the impact on the environment, I introduce these concepts to her in terms of her need to consider her remarks when we come to seeking to remove the excise in relation to buses and cars.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let Senator Watson's remarks pass without some comment. It is certainly true that some of the emissions from diesel are less than those from petrol engines. However, I point out to him that those who are experimenting with the diesohol mix—that is, 15 per cent alcohol in diesel—which, interestingly, is now being trialled in Sweden under Australian patents, found that the Australian diesel was so poor in quality that even in a very low concentration it could not be used to mix with the alcohol for export to Sweden. The experimenters had to import diesel from Sweden, mix it with the alcohol and then re-export it to Sweden. In our diesel we have very high levels of sulphur and also of polycyclic hydrocarbons, which are carcinogenic.

PARA.TAB: Our agreement with the government on this matter is to set proper standards in relation to Australian fuel. While it is certainly true that diesel is cleaner than petrol with respect to things such as carbon monoxide and unburnt hydrocarbons, by world standards both fuels in Australia are not particularly clean.
Question put:
That the request (Senator Margetts's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Progress reported.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (CUSTOMS) (WINE--DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993SALES TAX (EXCISE) (WINE--DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993SALES TAX (GENERAL) (WINE--DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, with minimum notice, reintroduced measures to impose a sales tax on wine; with even less notice, adjourned debate at the second reading stage; and, with even less notice still, brought on the debate again. I think this gives some indication of the lack of order and preparedness in the government's presentation of its bills this afternoon. The imposts in these new bills are at a lower rate than the original 1993 budget imposts on the wine industry which ranged up to an increase of 55 per cent. In other words, the government has now structured the sales tax bills so as to put the matters beyond constitutional challenge. I only wish that it had adopted such a responsible attitude earlier today with the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2).

PARA.TAB: There is a significant contradiction in the second reading speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Senator Faulkner). The government has been at pains to point out—and the minister points out in his second reading speech—that the government does not accept that any of the bills in this package impose tax. This has been a central thrust of what the government has been all about in terms of its presentation of the constitutional debate. However, within a few lines of the second reading speech, that statement is contradicted. It is amazing. The speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: For constitutional reasons, the sales tax is imposed by 4 Acts.
Here are the words:
Those Acts impose sales tax to the extent that it is:
a duty of customs;
a duty of excise;
a tax on in situ . . .

And it goes on. So here in the government's second reading speech is an inherent contradiction of its own argument throughout the whole of this constitutional debate. We are seeing an internal inconsistency, a contradiction; one wonders really whether the government understands what it is legislating for. There is a great deal of confusion.

PARA.TAB: A 31 per cent rate of tax on alcoholic wines will apply between budget night and the end of October, but from the end of October there will be a decrease in the rate of tax to 22 per cent, which will operate for only eight months. How much wine will be sold between today and 1 November? Who is going to pay a rate of 31 per cent when in the next month they will pay the rate of 22 per cent—a clear difference of nine percentage points?

But it does not stop there. From 1 July 1994 to 30 June 1995 the rate will increase to 24 per cent and from 1995 onwards it will increase to 26 per cent. This government is trying to get most of its tax imposts introduced early to overcome debate closer to the next election. Today we are seeing part of a package which increases indirect taxes to pay for the income tax cuts. In other words, income tax cuts are being subsidised and financed as a result of increased indirect taxes.

Had it not been for the stance taken by the Liberal and National party coalition, Australia would have had the highest taxes on wine anywhere in the world. The wine industry has to thank the Liberal and National party coalition for its stand on this. There have been significant reductions and they have been welcomed. From our perspective, the government promised no tax increases in this area, and it broke that election promise. In breaking that promise, at the same time it adopted thuggery and blackmail and tried to intimidate the industry. It tried to divide the industry between the small producers and the large producers. It was rather pathetic because the tactics employed actually did split the industry and they created divisions and concerns.

The government's blackmail was to threaten to impose an excise proposal. An excise proposal is an increase in tax at a time when it does not have to have legislative support through this parliament. What would that do to the wine industry? It would decimate its sales because one would never know when the legislation would come in and get knocked off. This was the dilemma faced by the industry. It could not afford such a hiatus, and it buckled. It is not surprising because a lot of the wine producers were facing bankruptcy, peril and division amongst their colleagues. This is a terrible state of affairs.

This division is typical of the Keating administration. We have seen it in Mabo, in the tax bills and in the thuggery of the negotiations and the blackmail that takes place. No wonder the industry is bitter and frustrated. We should remember that it was faced with that 55 per cent increase—a terrific impost. I only hope that the Greens and others will be able to produce a similar percentage reduction when we come to the excise duties. In that case people are facing not a 55 per cent increase but a 92 per cent increase in tax. This tax will severely impact on our export performance.

Indirect tax hikes of this magnitude are anathema to the Australian people and Australian business. We are really seeing a GST without the benefits to industry of the GST rebates. This government is imposing costs and making industry uncompetitive. I put it to the Senate that the Liberal and National party coalition will continue to oppose these increases if for no other reason than that we cannot endorse the sorts of tactics employed by the Labor Party in getting its alleged mandate on the books. It will not receive anywhere near its budget level of revenue. It will have a win but at great cost to the Australian community and at great cost to its own revenue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are hoping to get this package of bills through tonight, I will keep my remarks as brief as possible. I found it very interesting listening to Senator Watson when he said that he acknowledges the damage that all of this is doing to the industry and the damage it has done to the industry. It is estimated that lost sales have amounted to $75 million. I certainly agree that the Labor Party embarked on a whole series of actions that can best be described as holding not one but two guns to the head of the industry. There was the threat, as has already been outlined, of an excise proposal, and there was also the threat of people stopping buying wine, which is what the community has been doing. So there was a financial impost that the wine industry found unbearable.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I have to ask the Liberals why they want to prolong this matter. Why does the opposition end up in a position where it is totally out in the cold? If we do not support this package, as objectionable as we find the government's actions in terms of the means by which it was arrived at, we will be stretching out this agony for month after month. All the government will do is let this bill ricochet off to the House of Representatives where it will probably sit around. It does not have to bring it back for three months if it is defeated. Then we are looking at February.

The busiest period for the wine industry is coming up shortly, with Christmas. Indeed, it makes about one-third of its sales between now and 25 December. It is extremely urgent that we give this industry some respite. So it is beyond me to understand why the Liberals continue to pursue this agenda. It was through their opposition that the industry was able to get into a position where there could be some resolution. But now there is some resolution across the entire industry, bar perhaps four per cent of its work force. I am not talking about just the winemakers, who have been united from the start, but also the grape growers, who have consulted amongst their industry and brought that section almost on board, and the retail sales people, who perhaps at the moment are the most desperate to get this package through because they are the ones whose pockets are being hit immediately. The winemakers are being hit particularly with cellar door sales, and as yet the grape growers do not really understand the financial impost of what has been going on over the last couple of months.

I would like to suggest to members of the Liberal Party that now they are basically just acting as spoilers. They have lost this debate. Therefore, they are in a situation of digging themselves into a larger and larger hole by opposing this package which, I stress again, has been agreed to by the industry—an industry which, I suggest, is probably more united than it ever has been before. That is saying something about an industry that has already achieved an enormous amount without any government interference and without any direct government assistance.

The one positive thing that has come out of all of this is that an industry plan will now be developed. If we look to the old saying that `every cloud has a silver lining', the silver lining in this, as well as the fact that we now have an industry that is united across its various sections, is that we will have an industry plan that will hopefully put in place something that the industry will be proud to work towards and which the government will accept and not try to tamper with again by any impost, be it tax or any other alterations.

The reason we must pass this package is so that sales can start again. Most of the wine that has not been sold over the last few weeks will not be sold. Consumers will not now go out and buy and drink the wine that they have not drunk over the past weeks. If they did, the whole country would end up legless. But planning can begin. The wine catalogues for Christmas are sitting there simply waiting for the prices to be put on them before they are sent out. Planting can resume. In the several areas in South Australia where it was stopped, the various processes involved with arranging those plantings will now go ahead.

I cannot leave my remarks tonight without commenting on the activities of the Labor Party. I believe it had absolutely no idea of what its impost would do to this industry. The previous debates on the original bill showed that it had done no planning. Indeed, I cannot understand why the government has criticised us for listening to the wine industry, because it has no better source of information. Hopefully, after we have had this inquiry, all of us from all parties will be able to see where the wine industry is going, what support it needs and, hopefully, what interference it does not need in order to succeed.

The government could not challenge industry claims because it simply had no better source of information. As we went through the previous debate, it seemed that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) did not really know anything of the plan to increase the sales tax on wine until it was all decided, signed, sealed and printed. I believe the government stands condemned for what it has done to the Australian wine industry. Hopefully, it has now learnt some lessons about process and about how one goes about developing an industry policy.

The claims that have been made about the industry being forced to negotiate are quite true. I certainly do not condone the methods which the government used. But that does not mean that we now work around, or try to walk away from, the only means of getting this industry back on its feet. I urge the Liberals to think again, to stop this mindless opposition for the sake of opposing, and to look at what they are doing to one of Australia's most successful industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you agreed with us last week.

—Of course we supported the opposition on the 31 per cent, but we are not looking at that now; we are looking at a one per cent increase that the industry is prepared to live with. How about the Liberals also listening to the industry. It is only going to look at a one per cent increase this year and a two per cent increase in the next two years. I fully agree that the industry has been brought to the table, and by not accepting this agreement, we would do even more damage.
—Well, why are you agreeing with them?

—Because—in case Senator Ian Macdonald has not been listening—we would do even more damage to the wine industry. I stress again that the Democrats reached this position not only by negotiating with the leaders of the industry. I have spent time in the wine regions in South Australia, particularly in the Coonawarra and the Riverland, where I have met with people who disagree, but all of them are now on side and urging the Democrats to support this package.
—All of them on side?
—People in South Australia are no longer contacting me—not the growers, they signed on the dotted line yesterday.

PARA.TAB: I finish my remarks by congratulating Brian Croser, the immediate past president of the Winemakers Federation of Australia, on the outstanding commitment that he has shown to the wine industry. He and Ian Sutton, the chief executive officer, have led discussions and negotiations. Indeed, they have been seen from one side of this country to the other. Mr Croser will now be able to go back to the Piccadilly Valley in South Australia and get on with the other job that he is so good at and enjoys so much. The wine industry owes him an enormous debt of gratitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have made clear over time and during the last debate the concerns of the Greens (WA) about the 31 per cent sales tax impost on the wine industry, especially in relation to regional development and those things that do work at regional level, the government's purported desire to get regional development up and going and its purported desire to support employment initiatives. We have made that quite clear.

PARA.TAB: I will also give the Senate some idea of the kind of difficulty that we have found ourselves in in the last week or so in relation to the pleas and messages we had been receiving from the wine industry right across Australia, particularly from Western Australia. I will read some of the messages that we have received. This plea is on behalf of the east coast of Tasmania winemakers and grape growers:

SPEECH.PARA: Please oppose this terrible deal that Mr Croser has organised with the labour party. The wine farmers in this area feel that the concerns of the small producer are not being met. The wine makers federation gave no indication or chance for any of its members to vote or have a say in these deals.
This message, which comes from Pemberton in Western Australia, states:

We urge you to stand firm against proposed increase in sales tax on wine. Brian Croser has "sold" small producers up the river through political and economic pressure by Dawkins. Concessions needed urgently by small winemakers to enable them to survive have not been adequately addressed.
The South West Development Authority said:

The wine industry is of critical importance in our rapidly expanding tourism activity in our region, and any additional impost will limit that growth. The wine industry is also a substantial employer.
The capital investment required for the expansion of the wine industry will dry up with any tax increase.
You are urged to oppose the tax increase.
A plea from Mudgee states:
Please do not capitulate regarding wine tax proposal. We can't afford it and still survive.
A message received from the Margaret River area states:

In short we now urge you to withstand the pressures—which apparently pertain to represent this community and all other communities of small premium wine producers—but do not! Please do not allow the governments package to succeed as is.
This one, from Gunyulgup in Western Australia, states:
Don't compromise integrity due to the pressure from those who don't care.
Another plea from the Margaret River states:
The industry needs no cash grants, investment subsidies or any hidden sweeteners. What we do need is some understanding brought about by improved government-industry consultations.
This message, which comes from Elizabeth Bay in New South Wales, states:

Our company is appalled at the decision purportedly entered on behalf of the wine industry by the Wine Makers Federation of Australia. Attached is a copy of my fax sent this morning to Mr Brian Croser. We would urge you to continue your support for rejection to the Government's measures.

Having said all that, we have become aware that much of the problem has been related to the fact that very few of the winegrowers and producers in Australia know of the details of the package that was offered to the industry. The circumstances of the forced commitment by a number of people acting on behalf of the wine industry did not allow time—perhaps it could have been better handled—for communicating many of those issues. Many of those issues still have not been resolved. However, what has finally come through is a message, but not from all these people. Some of them have not forgiven, and will not forgive, the Labor Party for the way that it has acted in this measure. They have asked me to speak out loudly about their hurt and anger at the way that they have been treated as an industry.

PARA.TAB: My final quote is representative of what has now become, I suppose, a representative view of many parts of the industry:

SPEECH.PARA: There is really no other rational choice than to proceed with the recent Winemakers Federation of Australia's agreement with the Treasurer. No matter what transpires, the Treasurer will get increased taxation either as the wholesale tax, or an ad valorem excise. The industry cannot "win".

Is this the kind of negotiation and regional development strategy that this government wants? I am disgusted and so is the industry. It is not a win. It is a lose-lose situation. I hope that all those who were involved in this kind of dreadful exercise are ashamed of themselves.

PARA.TAB: We reluctantly support the package. It has some benefits for some sectors. It does not fully address the problems of the industry. However, we have asked the government to make sure that the inquiry that is part of the package is not just for show. As such, I believe that the government will be announcing, as part of the minister's speech, the agreement that it has reached with the Greens in relation to the minimum requirement that we believe is necessary for a regional based study of the impacts of this kind of government policy on the wine industry.

We will be watching the government like a hawk. I can tell the government that every sector of the wine industry—small and large growers and small and large producers—will also be watching it like a hawk to make sure that this study is representative, that it looks at regional implications, that it is fairly done and that the outcomes are properly considered.

In closing, I say that I believe that the Greens have once again been put in a very painful position. We feel for those people who are suffering. I would like to apologise to those people who may feel that we let them down by not continuing to hold out, even though they were hurting. Some people are still asking us to hold out on this legislation. In the end we had to make a decision on the balance, and the decision has fallen on the side of supporting the package and condemning the government for its method of operation in this manipulative process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can sympathise somewhat with Senator Margetts because when one considers the plight that this industry has been put in by the efforts of the government over the past two months, one can understand that when it comes down to a situation of blackmailing and bludgeoning the industry some people in the wine industry have found themselves in a desperate situation. I understood the concerns of Mr Croser and the people who belong to the Winemakers Federation when this government first came up with a 31 per cent sales tax on wine. I can understand the industry reaction and I can understand the grape growers reaction. I think the coalition was quite right to announce immediately that we would be opposing this tax. We have consistently opposed this legislation, and we will continue to oppose extra imposts on wine.

PARA.TAB: The fact that we announced that we were going to oppose this legislation gave other people the opportunity to start negotiating. Unfortunately, the industry was blackmailed by the government with threats of an increase in excise and various other ways and means of making sure that, in the long run, it would get its way in some form or other.

I can understand that over that period of two months—and we all know about the drop in sales and the difficulties the industry was going through—something had to give. The way the government treated matters was that the people who were going to give first were the big wine makers who had the most to lose through their sales and who were in the strongest position to negotiate. We have a government that is prepared to negotiate with the big wine makers and big wine sellers but it is prepared to forget about the small grape grower and small wine producers so that it can raise revenue.

I do not agree with Senator Lees when she says that the industry is more united than it has ever been. She is entitled to her point of view and maybe she has been talking to different people from those that I have been talking to. I tell the Senate that there are an enormous number of grape growers in South Australia who are still particularly unhappy with the package—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are unhappy but support it.

—Senator Margetts says they support it. I was talking to people the other day who are still not supporting the legislation. People are still contacting me about this matter. When it comes to the crunch the people who will suffer the most, as always, will be the people at the grape growing end and at the primary production end. Those groups will be squeezed in the same way that any other primary producer in any other industry in Australia will be squeezed. Eventually they have to bear the brunt of any taxes or extra imposts that are placed on the industry. The wine makers, particularly the large wine makers, are in a situation where the government can put the squeeze on them. It is the grape growers who will be most effected because they cannot do anything about the prices that they receive for the commodity they produce. The wine makers will be the ones who will eventually decide what price they will pay for that commodity. If they feel they have to squeeze the grape growers, then they will squeeze them.

PARA.TAB: This Labor Government has allied itself to the major wine growers and major wine makers in order to put pressure on the smaller grape growers. I am quite sure—

TALK.START.PARA: —The growth is in the grape industry.

—It is not funny. I could have mentioned before, when Senator Murphy was talking, the effect the increase in the fuel tax would have on his island state of Tasmania. We know he will vote against it eventually. In South Australia we are particularly concerned because something like 60 per cent of the grapes that are crushed are crushed in South Australia. When there is a state that is in the economic situation that South Australia is in and an extra impost is going to be placed on the one industry that looks like it is succeeding and doing well, we find that the economy of South Australia is going to suffer even more greatly than it is at present.

PARA.TAB: The other thing the government said in this budget was how this budget was all about jobs. I have read this over and over again and we heard again yesterday that this budget is about jobs. How on earth there is ever going to be any increase in jobs in the wine industry while there is an increase in costs and an increase in tax on the wine industry I am at a loss to understand. It will take this industry some time to recover from the impact this proposal will have on it. In conclusion I say that the way the government has handled this whole deal over the past two months, the way that it has blackmailed the industry, the way that it has been heavy handed with the industry and, in particular, with the big wine makers in order to get what it wants from those who it knows can afford to pay, is unacceptable. Some of the big wine makers have admitted that they can afford to pay. It is only the people at the lower end of the scale who are going to suffer. They are the ones that I am particularly concerned about. I am concerned about the Riverland of South Australia where we already have one of the lowest incomes per capita in Australia and struggling grape growers as well as struggling fruit growers. In the Clare Valley and the Barossa Valley many people are suffering because that area has among the lowest income per capita in Australia. The wine industry is undeserving of the extra imposts that will be placed on it. From the start we have been consistent in our opposition to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Ferguson. I reiterate the great concern that we have on this side of the chamber about the thuggery and blackmail which has been applied against one of our real growth export sectors in the economy. I doubt that I can ever recall a government which is seen to be more vindictive towards one particular industry.

—May be there are other sectors that the government has been vindictive towards, but I cannot recall them. We have in my home state a growth industry and an industry which is performing particularly well.

—Can you recall this document?

—I am so glad Senator Bolkus has reminded me. Senator Bolkus is holding up the election results. I ask Senator Bolkus: when the government went around during the election campaign where did it say it was going to raise the wine tax? Where did it say it was going to raise the fuel tax? Where did it say it was going to raise the wholesale sales tax? It did not say so once. It lied its way into office and it did not have the revenue in order to sustain its promises and so it imposed a whole range of taxes on the Australian economy, taxes which are going to cost jobs.

PARA.TAB: I think it goes further than that. We have seen a degree of thuggery, vindictiveness and blackmail. As Senator Lees said, at the end of the day the balance has to be drawn. The wine producers have been singled out for particular attention. In the end it is quite clear from what the major spokespeople in the wine industry have said that they simply have to resolve this issue; it is thus far and no further.

I think it is a real dilemma. I think Senator Lees and the Greens have put a particular view; we have all wrestled with this problem. It is worth recording the utterly disgraceful behaviour of the Labor Party. On this side of the chamber we are not going to condone blackmail and therefore we will be opposing this particular measure. At the end of the day it is a balance that has to be drawn.

The Labor Party has singled out this particular industry. I doubt whether it will ever forget what the Labor Party has done. I certainly hope that it will not and that a heavy punishment is meted out to the Labor Party for its behaviour towards this industry over the past three or four months.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you were in government you'd increase taxes again.

—The smiling senator from Tasmania again thinks that this is a hell of a joke. It is not a hell of a joke. If he had ever visited a winery and if he had seen what his policies have done, he would not be smiling now. He would be weeping in shame, and that is exactly what he should be doing. It has been absolutely appalling.

PARA.TAB: I wish to raise a couple of other matters. Not only has the wine industry been hit with these additional taxes; it has been hit with additional fuel taxes. This has been a double barrelled effect. The wine industry has not been singled out for the additional cost that the fuel tax rises will make. Nonetheless, this is an additional cost that the wine industry must bear.

It is a lesson to the whole Australian community that we simply cannot trust members of the Labor Party. They lied their way into office; they were not honest with the people. Now they are faced with the problem of having to raise all this revenue. As a consequence, they have sought to gain in a whole variety of ways the additional billions of dollars which are required to fund the unfinanced tax cuts.

I am afraid that, at the end of the day, the government has to set priorities. We have just seen, for example, that the government was able to provide $107 million to the island of Nauru. The damage that has been done to the wine industry will raise in the order of $40 million. If those opposite throw out the largess and make big people of themselves all the time, then, at the end of the day, that has to be paid for. This particular tax is one of the many taxes which have been imposed. I support the remarks of my colleagues. I absolutely abhor the blackmail that the Labor Party has practised in this area. This has been an appalling exercise and Australian industry would do well to take note of the way the Labor Party, led by Mr Keating, now behaves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that some comments ought to be made in relation to this matter before it is finally put to rest one way or other. A good deal has been said about the ramifications of a tax for the wine industry. I will not go over that in detail. I want to concentrate on the position of the Western Australian winegrowers. Initially the position taken by the winegrowers in the west was that they were totally opposed to the proposal of an 11 per cent increase in wine tax. More recently, there have been press reports that the Western Australian winegrowers gave in and agreed with the proposal as put forward by the government today. I wish to advise the Senate that that is not the case.

PARA.TAB: In the last week or so it was put to the Western Australian winegrowers that they should accept the deal struck by the federation with the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). They had no input, no warning. In fact, to my knowledge the only community meeting which has ever been held on this point in the country was held in the south west of Western Australia, at Margaret River, last Sunday. A meeting of more than 100 people, involving community people as well as winegrowers, passed a motion in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The Margaret River/Swan Valley, Pemberton members of Great Southern wine communities are philosophically opposed to any increase in wholesale sales tax on wine. However, in the interests of industry stability we are prepared to accept an increase to 22 per cent from 1 November 1993 or at an earlier date if agreed by parliament, provided that an industry inquiry is instituted. No further wholesale sales tax increases are to be implemented without the approval of parliament.

That says that because of pressure brought to bear on them and the threat that it would destabilise the industry, they gave in to an increase to 22 per cent only. They did not agree to subsequent increases of two per cent for each year for the next three years. Nor did they agree to any retrospective ratification of an increase to 31 per cent since 17 August this year, when the budget was brought in.

PARA.TAB: From the dealings I have had with the growers there—and I have spoken to the president and a number of other people who were at that meeting in Margaret River last Sunday—I know that they would welcome an inquiry, but they feel that to increase taxes over the next three years prior to any inquiry or the result of any inquiry is prejudicial, to say the least, and is prejudging the issue in the extreme. In fact, honourable senators will note that in their motion they stated that there should be no further wholesale sales tax increase without the approval of parliament. They have all said to me that they welcome an inquiry. They have no problems with that. They have nothing to hide. But they all stressed to me that they had been coerced into this position. The law of contract states that duress or fraud can void a contract. In this case they had a good deal of duress. They had the threat from the Treasurer saying, `I will impose an excise on you if you do not agree.'

TALK.START.PARA: —A promise.

—I could point a gun at Senator Burns and say `It is a promise that I will not shoot'; `promise' is another word for a threat. As well as that, there was the package under this heads of agreement, which I understood some winegrowers in Western Australia saw for the first time last Sunday, despite it having been negotiated over a period of time. That package, which does not form part of this bill but which forms the backdrop to the negotiations to bring it in, holds some inducement to the larger winegrowers because it provides for a capital write-off for acquisition of vines and vineyards.

PARA.TAB: If you are a large winegrower, that is a great incentive. Large winegrowers simply want to get bigger. It gives them an opportunity to acquire smaller vineyards. A letter was faxed to me from one of the larger vineyards. It is dated 6 November 1992, from Petaluma Ltd to its investors, and signed by Brian Croser. One sentence in it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Our intention is to expand by the acquisition of premium wine producers on terms that will add value to Petaluma's business and the brand names acquired.

I put it to the Senate that the interests of the larger winegrowers are different to those of the smaller winegrowers in Western Australia, whom I am here representing and speaking on behalf of today. Western Australia is in an unusual situation because it has so many small winegrowers. I am not criticising the large winegrowers because they want to acquire further vineyards and expand their production. That is natural; it is in the course of things. But I query whether this package is designed to protect the smaller winegrowers or whether it has been designed to induce the larger winegrowers to participate in this package and to bring their fellow winegrowers, the smaller ones, around to agreeing to this package.

PARA.TAB: The small winegrower was like a grape being caught in a vice. On one side you had the Treasurer saying, `Stand and deliver or I will impose an excise'. On the other side you had other vested interests who had their own reasons for seeing this package come in.

I address my comments to the press. I say to them, `Your reports that the Western Australian winegrowers gave in to this package are wrong. You should get your facts right and go back to the drawing board'. What I say to the people who say that the Western Australian winegrowers agree with this package is that they are absolutely wrong. The motion that I have read grudgingly concedes the two per cent increase and freely acknowledges `let us have an inquiry' but it does not go along with a package, or the heads of agreement that was entered into by the federation and the Treasurer. In fact, that motion was passed 98 to 2. All the small winegrowers backed it because they did not see that they had any choice.

SPEECH.PARA: A report which was commissioned by the state government of Western Australia concluded with the following remarks:

By increasing the wine tax, growth in the wine industry will be lower. This will set back an industry which is increasingly generating exports and which is a major source of regional rather than centralised growth in Western Australia and Australia. Western Australian wineries which are smaller than those in the eastern states will be particularly vulnerable to reduction in revenue resulting from the tax.

I put it to the Senate that whether it be two per cent or 11 per cent, it does not matter. Any increase in the tax on these small wine growers will be disastrous. In fact, as one small winegrower put to me, a bottle of wine has $2 tax on it but a cask of wine has 22c tax on it. It is the larger wine producers who produce the casks of wine. The small wine growers that I am talking about in the south-west of Australia produce bottled wine. Therefore, they suffer an already disproportionate rate of tax compared with cask wine.

PARA.TAB: The record needs to be set straight. This was a very grubby deal which was put together. Anybody who says that the coalition is being obstructionist needs to look at themselves before they accuse us of being obstructionist in this matter. If others want to go along with grubby deals whereby small wine growers are coerced into agreeing, and if they want to go along with a threat to blackmail them and bring in an excise, let it be on their own heads. For the coalition's part, we see this as a corrupt political exercise whereby the small business men and women have been caught in a vice.

I might say, these people are out of the ordinary because they do a lot more for the community than the average business does. In fact, at that meeting in Margaret River there were people like the refrigeration fellow who supplied the refrigeration on the vineyards and people from the tourist industry. In 1991, in the south-west region of Western Australia $84 million was spent by tourists on overnight stays. They went there mainly because of the vineyards and the pleasant environment that these wine growers have helped to create.

On the question of the environment, I know that the Green senators would readily acknowledge that these people are also very environmentally conscious in the way they conduct their business. What do they get for it? They get a stand and deliver approach by the Treasurer. They get coerced into accepting a deal which is totally unfair to them. The considerations which apply to them are different from those applying to the larger winegrowers. The coalition opposes this tax on well considered grounds which we have maintained consistently throughout the debate.

These winegrowers are on the way up. They are trying to establish themselves. They are trying to get a sufficient toehold in the domestic market so that they can export. Eighty per cent of the work force they employ are young people. Any tax impost on these growers is just going to put them backwards.
Just as an aside, when these winegrowers give their wine away for tastings at the cellar door, they get taxed on that as well. It is great! They get taxed for giving wine away.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is in the package. That has been done.
—I can tell Senator Lees right now that the people—
—Have you read the package?

—I can say to Senator Lees that the main incentive of the package is for the larger winegrowers because of the capital write-offs by acquiring further properties. That is the very cruncher which these small winegrowers face. I oppose this strongly. I did look at the possibility that maybe rejecting the initial measure was sufficient. It was put to me, `Enough is enough. We've achieved what people wanted'. At one stage I was nearly satisfied that we had. I thought, `Yes, perhaps that's it. We should go along with this proposal'. But when I inquired further and found out what had gone on, when I found out what the true feelings were of the small winegrowers from my state, I felt compelled to rise to oppose this.

I think that subsection has already been amended by Senator Harradine's amendment earlier which was to take out item 11(E)(2) from that schedule. As that has already been taken out, I think my amendment can remain in the form that we had earlier contemplated. If surprisingly we get the numbers, the balance of the provisions will be taken out. I think that is the correct interpretation. Certainly that is the advice that I have been given.

The fourth is to omit from page 7 of the schedule proposed subsection 6AAA(7). I say to those who do not understand it that if they just vote with us they know they will be getting rid of these awful excise increases! The seventh is the omission of item 10 from page 8 of the schedule. Item 10 amends paragraphs 11(A)(3)(b) of the schedule to the principal act—that is, gasoline—by omitting subparagraph (b) and introducing new subparagraphs (b) and (c) to introduce the differentiation between leaded and unleaded gasoline and providing for an increase in the excise duty of 3c per litre for both.

Item 12 amends paragraph 11(C)(2) of the schedule of the principal act, relating to coal tar distillate suitable for use as gasoline substitutes, by omitting paragraph (2) and introducing two new subparagraphs (b) and (c) to introduce the differentiation between leaded and unleaded coal tar, distillates and providing for a 3c per litre increase in the excise for both.

Those increases will substantially add to business costs, detrimentally affect employment and also, as I said in an earlier debate, they will particularly affect the less well off in our community—the regressive part, again, of this budget. This Labor government does not seem to be particularly concerned if, through its tax changes, it hurts most the poor within our community through its tax changes. This is the chance for the Senate to get rid of these increases. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, I regard amendments 10 to 17A as a group in that they all relate to item 13 of the government's bill. PARA.TAB: I have sought to break the government's item up into, as I said, separate subgroupings in order that the vote might be taken separately on each because there may well be a different result within the Senate on each. I want first to move my amendment No. 10, which has the effect of taking off the government's intended increase of 3c a litre and bringing it back to what it was previously, which was 0.26573c a litre, in relation to automotive diesel oil other than for use in rail or road transport services.

I am particularly thinking of road transport. I am thinking of all those small Australian haulage companies that work, I think, in one of the hardest fields. For small business people, they are forced to outlay large capital sums. They work incredible hours. They scrape by in my experience, if they get by at all, and they really need every opportunity to make a living.

To have the cost of their fuel increased further by this excise represents, I hope, a failure on the part of the government to understand the consequence to such small businesses. Diesel, as I understand—others might know better than I—is an environmentally friendly fuel in any event. I particularly want to mention the road haulage industry because it is critically important to a country such as ours, with obviously a large land mass, with cities sparingly placed and with a minimum of rail. I would like to encourage more rail, but obviously there is enormous capital expenditure involved in extending rail. In many cases, as my friend Senator Panizza would confirm, there is no choice but to use road haulage for the purpose of getting product to market or goods and services out to farms and to regional areas. I hope that, on reflection, the committee will recognise that also and will vote down the increase in that area.

He will no doubt argue persuasively that the Greens and the Democrats should recognise that also and vote down the excise increase on that.

I will leave my remarks at that at this stage. I have made the point that the opposition obviously supports the removal of excise in all of these distinct areas. I hope we can persuade others in the chamber to support us in at least the majority of those areas. I therefore move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, but there is just one issue that I wish to raise tonight. In question time today, I asked the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, a question regarding the tragic crash of the RAAF Boeing 707 aircraft and subsequent actions taken by the air force to notify pilots of the potential dangers of double asymmetric training. I asked this question because of my concern that there appears to be a misconception that only 707 aircraft are involved in the double asymmetric training when, in fact, Hercules and Orion aircraft also perform this procedure.

PARA.TAB: In his answer to my question, Senator Ray said that the RAAF will upgrade its Boeing 707 flight simulator and that tenders will be called next year. No mention was made of upgrading the Hercules and the Orion simulators and, on contacting Senator Ray's office this afternoon, it was confirmed that the Minister's answer only related to the 707 aircraft. However, I believe that, despite what Senator Ray said earlier today, Hercules and Orion aircraft regularly carry out double asymmetric training. As with the 707 simulator, neither the Hercules nor the Orion simulators are capable of simulating the conditions necessary for double asymmetric training.

Being from South Australia, I am particularly concerned about this situation as it affects Orion pilots based at the Edinburgh air force base in Adelaide. I certainly do not pretend to be an expert on this topic. However, I am informed that double asymmetric training forms a necessary part of training in emergency procedures for aircraft such as the Orion.

As I stated in my question to the minister, Orions regularly fly with one engine shut down to conserve fuel. This is because Orions in their surveillance work cover large distances often over oceans. Naturally, Orions are often flying low and at low speeds. With one engine deliberately shut down, there only needs to be one unplanned engine failure on the same wing for the pilot to need to recall the double asymmetric training.

I do not want to make this sound overly dramatic but, firstly, if a second engine on the same wing does shut down, perhaps due to a bird strike or something similar, the normal procedure is to relight the other engine—the one that had been deliberately shut down. Secondly, as we have learned from the Boeing 707 crash, as long as the aircraft does not go below the minimum control speed, there is no reason why it cannot be flown safely. However, for the plane to be flown safely under such circumstances, obviously, the pilot must be familiar with the emergency procedures and the limits of the aircraft—the most important limit being the minimum control speed.

Without wishing to play down the importance of this issue to 707 and Hercules aircraft, I think it is important to point out that Orion aircraft regularly fly low over water and land and at low speed; they fly long hours over vast distances; and, most importantly, they regularly operate with one engine deliberately shut down. Because of this, it stands to reason that Orions are the aircraft that are most likely to have two engines fail on one wing while they are flying at a low speed.

In addition to that, Australia has 19 Orions which would cost over $100 million each to replace; we also have 24 Hercules worth tens of millions of dollars each. By contrast, I believe we only have five Boeing 707s worth about $8 million each. Orions also have the largest crew of these three aircraft usually carrying 15 flight crew on board plus any passengers; yet there seems to be some doubt that the Orion simulator will also be updated.

If the RAAF is to improve the standard of double asymmetric training, the same standard must apply across the air force. Otherwise, how can the RAAF justify to Orion pilots that their need for a simulator is less than that of the 707 pilots? What would happen if, several years down the track, an Orion pilot who was prevented from taking part in double asymmetric training, accidentally and through lack of knowledge and practice, let a plane go below its minimum control speed and crashed, killing those on board? When the RAAF is sued by wives of 15 flight crew, how will it justify Boeing 707 pilots being able to practise double asymmetric training in a simulator but Orion pilots not being able to—and, worse than that, the Orion pilot not having known what to do because he or maybe she had never been allowed to do the training in the air?

These are very serious questions and, if I have understood Senator Ray's answer to my question correctly, I believe the outcome is most unsatisfactory and I am sure that Orion pilots will be justifiably very angry. To bring the RAAF in line with current practices, both in the military and civilian world, Hercules and Orion simulators must also be upgraded without delay. This will lead to a reduction in the need, or maybe the elimination of the need, for RAAF flight crew to undertake double asymmetric training in the air.

In the meantime, while the simulators are being updated, the Minister for Defence and the RAAF hierarchy should ensure that all pilots—particularly Boeing 707, Orion and Hercules pilots—are formally notified of the chain of events which led to the tragic crash of the Boeing 707 in 1991. To this extent, I welcome Senator Ray's comments that written and video material is currently being prepared. But I would point out that it has been two whole years since the 707 crash and, as at yet, air force pilots, including those involved in double asymmetric training, have not received formal written advice as to the probable cause of the crash. This begs the

SPEECH.PARA: question: what if another crash similar to that had occurred during this period or what if one happened tomorrow?

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge Senator Ray's comments about the risks of double asymmetric training. But I think this only strengthens the arguments that, firstly, pilots are properly trained in this procedure, which the Boeing crash vividly demonstrates; and, secondly, as acknowledged by overseas Defence Forces and international airlines, it is preferable to practise this procedure in a simulator.

In conclusion, while I welcome Senator Ray's statement that tenders will be called for a level 5 simulator for the 707 aircraft, I believe this is only the beginning of the process. There is no doubt that Australia lags behind international standards on double asymmetric training and, until they are all upgraded, the risk of a similar incident is not diminished.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 13 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When was the moratorium on the development of food irradiation technology lifted.
(2) Is the National Food Authority conducting an inquiry into the development of food irradiation technology for use in Australia.
(3) Are there any foods currently for sale in Australia that have been irradiated.
(4) Do any labelling requirements apply stating that these foods have been irradiated.
(5) What is the type of radiation that is normally used to irradiate foods.
(6) Does irradiating food cause any unfavourable changes in its chemical structure or nutritional makeup.
(7) Can food irradiation be used to enhance the appeal of foods that may have exceeded their point of saleability.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The three year moratorium imposed in 1989 on the manufacture, sale and importation of irradiated food has been extended until the National Food Authority makes a recommendation to the National Food Standards Council on a standard for food irradiation.

(2) The National Food Authority is in the process of developing a standard for food irradiation which may prohibit or permit either generally or conditionally, the use of ionising radiation to treat food or particular classes of food. It is considering the issues involved with food irradiation in detail, taking into account the latest scientific evidence and with the extensive public consultation required under the National Food Authority Act 1991.

(3) As all exporting countries and Australian importers are fully aware of the Australian moratorium and of the need to use alternative methods of processing to ensure food meets Australian microbiological standards, it is highly unlikely that irradiated food is available for sale in Australia.
(4) As irradiation is not currently permitted, no labelling requirements apply.

(5) Ionising radiation of known energy is normally used to irradiate food. Four sources of radiation are recognised as suitable from a technical point of view—cobalt-60, caesium-137, electron beam and x-ray generators.

(6) Any preservative process applied to food (eg pasteurisation or cooking) will result in changes to its chemical structure and nutritional makeup. Whether changes which may occur as a result of irradiation are unfavourable is the subject of a Review of the Safety and Nutritional Adequacy of Irradiated Food, undertaken by the World Health Organisation (WHO) in 1992, at the request of the Commonwealth Government. The final report of this review is expected to be published by the WHO at the end of 1993 and will be publicly available.

(7) Food irradiation is used to preserve food. Depending upon the dose administered, the effect can range from pest disinfestation, through elimination of storage organisms, akin to pasteurisation, to industrial sterility. Irradiation can destroy micro organisms present in food but it cannot destroy odours, taste or the off-appearance of spoiled food. The process cannot therefore be used to restore or enhance the appeal of foods which have deteriorated beyond saleable condition.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 August 1993, (Hansard page 631) Senator Alston asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question without notice concerning the impact of the 1993-94 Budget on family incomes.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

It will always be possible to construct hypothetical instances of individuals or families who are apparently caused major distress out of any Budget change, depending on assumptions made about smoking and other living habits, family circumstances and the like.

In my press release of 31 August 1993, I released the results of a distributional analysis which incorporated as large a number of 1993-94 Budget measures as possible (including the modification of the personal income tax rebate that was announced on 30 August 1993). The analysis was conducted by the Treasury using the Price, Revenue and Incidence Simulation Model, PRISMOD. The press release, which should be read in conjunction with the model's results, provides a description of the type of Budget measures included in the distributional analysis, the operation of the PRISMOD model and caveats on the interpretation of its results. Importantly, the PRISMOD analysis is based on households, not individuals, so that in any one household there may be one or more income earners claiming the $150 rebate.

Table 2 of the press release shows estimates of percentage changes in real disposal income of 14 household types by income quintile of the budget measures modelled by PRISMOD. As discussed in paragraphs 10 to 14 of Attachment A to the press release, changes in real disposable income are likely to be a more useful guide to the impact on households than net cash gains shown in Table 1 of the press release, because the former avoid the use of implied saving ratios in the Australian Bureau of Statistics Household Expenditure Survey.
Bearing in mind the limitations and caveats associated with the PRISMOD analysis referred to above, Table 2 of the press release shows that on

ANSWER.PARA: the basis of the 1993-94 Budget measures modelled by PRISMOD, real disposable income will increase on average by less than one per cent in a majority of the 14 household types and income groups shown in the table, while for the remaining household types and income groups, there is a small loss in real disposable income of less than 0.15 per cent. The result for families in the lowest income quintile group is in line with the overall result for all households and income types, with real disposable income increasing on average by less than one per cent in almost all of the 14 household types in this income quintile.
